LOAN AND PROJECT SUMMARY 
 
 
Borrower  Republic of Uzbekistan  
   
Classification  Targeting classification: General intervention 
Sector: Education 
Subsector: Basic education 
Theme: Inclusive social development 
Subtheme: Human development  
   
Environment  Category C  
Assessment    
   
Project Description  The Project is aimed at improving the quality and relevance of and 
access  to  basic  education  by  integrating  information  and 
communications  technology  (ICT)  in  teaching  and  learning  in 
Uzbekistan. The Project will have four components: (i) establish 
operational school clusters as a network that covers all schools in 
Uzbekistan, and equip 860 cluster leader schools (CLSs) with ICT 
facilities and internet/intranet connectivity (the CLSs will provide 
essential pedagogical and technical support for effective ICT use 
in other schools in the clusters, including those in poor, rural, and 
remote areas); (ii) train staff for effective ICT use in schools, and 
improve the existing in-service teacher training system to make it 
more flexible and effective for training for ICT use across the 
curriculum; (iii) develop learning materials for ICT use; and (iv) 
provide advisory services on technical, financial, and fiscal issues 
to  the  Government  to  strengthen  sustainability  of  the 
Government’s  ICT  in  basic  education  policy,  and  pilot  test 
approaches designed to enhance project sustainability and future 
ICT development with a pro-poor focus. 
   
Rationale  In recognition of the potential gains offered by ICT to (i) improve 
the quality of education, (ii) strengthen the relevance of education 
to an increasingly information- and knowledge-based society and 
changing  labor  market  needs,  and  (iii)  improve  access  to 
education for children from poor families and in remote areas, the 
Government prepared a national strategy for ICT development in 
2002. The strategy provides a general framework and identifies 
basic  education  as  a  priority  sector  for  implementation.  In 
accordance with this strategy, and within the framework of the 
National Program for Basic Education Development approved in 
2004, the Government has launched an ambitious program to 
integrate ICT in schools nationwide. The Government considers 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  assistance  as  essential  in 
implementing  its  ICT  in  basic  education  program.  ADB  has 
assisted  the  Government  in  preparing  a  national  strategy  for 
integrating ICT in schools, to which the Project is anchored.

iv   
Impact and Outcome  The impact of the Project is the improved quality and relevance of, 
and equitable access to basic education for all students, including 
students in poor and remote areas. The outcome of the Project is 
the improvement of learning outcomes through ICT use in priority 
subject areas in grades 5–9 in project schools with a pro-poor 
focus.  The  priority  subject  areas  are  mathematics,  sciences, 
history, and languages, in addition to informatics. 
   
Cost Estimates  The  total  cost  of  the  Project  is  estimated  at  $43.0  million 
equivalent, including physical and price contingencies, taxes and 
duties, and interest and other charges. Of the total cost, $26.1 
million  (61%)  comprises  the  foreign  exchange  cost,  and  16.9 
million equivalent (39%) the local currency cost.

Loan Amount and Terms  A loan in various currencies equivalent to Special Drawing Rights 
20,408,000 from ADB’s Special Funds resources will be provided. 
The loan will have a 32-year term, including a grace period of 8 
years, with an interest rate of 1% per annum during the grace 
period and 1.5% per annum thereafter.  
   
Period of Utilization  Until 30 June  2011 
   
Estimated Project   
Completion Date  31 December 2010  
   
Implementation   The Project will integrate its management with that of ongoing 
Arrangements   projects  in  basic  education  to  reduce  transaction  costs  and 
maximize  economic  efficiency  in  project  implementation.  In 
particular, the project steering committee (PSC) will be integrated 
with the PSCs for the two ongoing ADB projects with the Ministry 
of Public Education (MOPE): the Education Sector Development 
Program (ESDP), and the Second Textbook Development Project 
(STDP). Members of the existing PSCs include representatives of 
the  Cabinet  of  Ministers,  MOPE,  and  Ministry  of  Finance. 
Participation may be adjusted to meet the needs of the Project. 
The PSC will also consider appointing the project director for the 
ESDP and STDP as the project director for the Project. Given 
MOPE’s  experience  with  ADB  project  implementation, 
accumulated since 1998, and the recent successful completion of 
the  Basic  Education  Textbook  Development  Project,  financial 
management  arrangements  of  MOPE  are  satisfactory  for 
purposes of implementation of the Project.

v
  The project implementation unit (PIU) will be responsible for day-
to-day  management  of  the  Project  including  procurement  and 
recruitment;  staff  development;  finance  and  accounting; 
monitoring  and  evaluation;  and  preparation  of  detailed  project 
implementation plans and annual and quarterly progress reports 
for submission to the PSC, the project director, and ADB. The PIU 
will  have  6–8  full-time  staff  with  expertise  in  these  areas.  To 
ensure  timely  start-up  of  project  implementation,  MOPE  will 
appoint a project manager, who will be responsible for day-to-day 
coordination of project activities. The PIU will be established in 
accordance  with  a  government  decision  related  to  the 
establishment and financing of this PIU, which will be covered by 
retroactive financing (para. 57). The PIU will be established in the 
same premises as the ESDP and STDP PIUs, and will coordinate 
closely with them across PIU functions, including sharing of staff 
where feasible. Eventual consideration will be given to measures 
to further harmonize project management. 
   
Executing Agency  Ministry of Public Education  
   
Procurement  The Project will procure (i) standard packages of ICT hardware 
and peripherals, and related furniture and other equipment for 860 
CLSs;  (ii)  non-personal-computer-based  learning  materials  and 
equipment  including  audiovisual  sets;  and  (iii)  furniture  and 
computers for office and administrative use. ADB loan-financed 
goods and services will be procured following ADB’s Guidelines 
for  Procurement.  Procurement  of  largest  value  will  be  for  ICT 
hardware,  which  may  be  broken  into  several  packages  each 
larger  than  $1  million  to  allow  proper  sequencing  of  ICT 
installation in schools. Goods and services will be procured by 
international competitive bidding where the cost is valued at more 
than $1 million equivalent, or by international shopping where the 
cost  is  valued  from  $100,000  to  $1  million  equivalent.  Direct 
purchase may be applicable for goods and services valued at less 
than  $100,000  equivalent.  Procurement  of  furniture  and  the 
development of software and e-materials valued at less than $0.5 
million  per  contract  may  follow  local  competitive  bidding 
procedures acceptable to ADB. The Government will finance and 
undertake necessary civil works, in particular to rehabilitate and 
upgrade computer classrooms. Minimum criteria to be met by a 
school prior to installation of ICT equipment have been agreed.  
   
Consulting Services  The Project will require 212 person-months of consulting services, 
consisting  of  52.5  person-months  of  international  and  159.5 
person-months  of  domestic  consulting.  Areas  of  expertise 
required include education reform and decentralization, software 
development,  ICT  in  basic  education,  training,  continuous 
professional  development  (CPD),  school  networking,  and  pilot 
project  design  and  evaluation.  International  consultants  will  be 
engaged through a firm in association with domestic consultants 
using quality and cost-based selection with full technical proposals

vi   
  in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants. 
PIU  staff  will  be  recruited  separately  using  arrangements 
satisfactory to ADB.   
                    
Project Benefits and  The direct benefit of applying ICT across the curriculum will be a 
Beneficiaries  fundamental  shift  to  student-centered  learning  and  teaching 
methodologies. This will lead to improved student performance in 
priority subject areas, and enhanced skills and competencies as 
opposed to the accumulation of factual knowledge. ICT use will 
motivate  students  and  teachers  by  making  education  more 
relevant.  These  combined  will  have  a  positive  impact  on  the 
overall  system  to  produce  graduates  with  the  ability  to  meet 
working  life  challenges  in  the  21st  century  with  increasingly 
advanced skills in information access, management, processing, 
and usage. The Project will significantly improve the effectiveness 
of  the  CPD  system  for  teachers.  The  establishment  of  school 
clusters and the close working conditions required between the 
existing  teaching  training  institutions  and  the  CLSs  to  be 
established under the Project will make the content of CPD more 
relevant and its delivery more effective. The Project will also lay 
the foundation for the planned second phase of ICT development 
after 2010.  
   
The Project will directly benefit 540,000 students in grades 5–9 in 
the  860  CLSs  through  the  improved  learning  and  teaching 
conditions resulting from the provision and application of ICT in 
classrooms. Direct beneficiaries will also include 7,740 teachers in 
CLSs,  63,200  teachers  in  non-CLSs,  1,720  CLS  school 
management staff, 17,800 management staff in non-CLSs, 220 
teacher trainers, and 600 local language e-materials developers, 
whose skills will be improved by the targeted training under the 
Project. Given the proposed central role of the CLSs in the school 
system, all students and teachers in the basic education system 
will benefit from the Project. This will amount to about 6 million 
students and 200,000 teachers during 2006–2010. Finally, over 1 
million households are estimated to be able to benefit from ICT 
use  when  schools  open  their  ICT  facilities  to  access  in  their 
communities. The Project will benefit the poor disproportionately 
as about 70% of CLSs are in poor, rural, and remote areas; the 
Project will provide the disadvantaged with equitable access to 
information from the internet/intranet as well as pedagogical and 
technical support for effective ICT use.  
   
Risks and Assumptions  The Project faces three major types of risks. The first are risks 
related to adoption of new technology. Using ICT in schools is 
new; over 50% of schools have never had access to computers. 
The risks of inadequate and inappropriate use of ICT as well as 
mismanagement  of  the facilities will  be  high. These risks  will be

vii
  mitigated by extensive capacity building for teachers and school 
management  to  ensure  intended  use  and  impact  of  ICT  in 
schools.   
 
The second are infrastructure and logistical risks. For the effective 
use of ICT in schools, the Project will require a number of basic 
infrastructure  and  logistical  conditions  to  be  met,  including 
appropriate classroom facilities with security arrangements, power 
supply,  internet/intranet  connectivity,  and  services  and 
maintenance. These concerns are addressed through covenanted 
assurances.  
 
The third are financial sustainability risks. Throughout the design 
of the Project, the financial implications of the integration of ICT 
have been carefully reviewed and extensive consultations held 
with  the  Government  to  ensure  that  the  Project  and  the 
Government’s  plans  for  integrating  ICT  in  basic  education  are 
financially  sustainable.  The  Project  addresses  these  concerns 
through (i) covenants on adequate and timely budget provision for 
operation and maintenance and replacement costs; (ii) piloting of 
low  cost  hardware  configurations;  and  (iii)  a  strong  focus  on 
financial  sustainability  during  project  reviews,  including  the 
midterm review.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the Republic of Uzbekistan for the Information and Communications Technology in Basic 
Education Project. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
 
2.  According to the Constitution of Uzbekistan, all citizens are entitled to basic education. 
Provided by the public sector, basic education starts at age 6/7 and comprises grades 1–9 with 
an additional 2 years of high school in grades 10 and 11. This 11-year system is due to be 
phased out by 2010 when it will be replaced by a 12-year system, which will be compulsory. The 
12-year system will provide 3 years of senior secondary education after grade 9 either in 
academic  lyceums  or  in  technically  and  vocationally  oriented  professional  colleges.  The 
restructuring of basic and senior secondary education has been a focus of sector reforms since 
1997. Higher education consists of a 4-year first degree program followed by a 2-year masters 
program and then a doctoral program. Information on the basic education system is in Appendix 
2.  
 
3.  In 2003/04 about 6.1 million students were enrolled in basic education. With a net 
enrolment  rate  estimated  at  over  98%  and  no  significant  gender  differentials  in  primary 
education,  Uzbekistan  scores  high  on  the  two  Millennium  Development  Goals  relevant  to 
education. However, the level of attendance is reported to be a problem especially in poor 
regions, although reliable data is not available. The primary completion rate is estimated to be 
close to 100%. Over the next 5 years basic education enrolment is expected to decrease due to 
(i)  the  transfer  of  approximately  600,000  grade  10  and  11  students  to  senior  secondary 
education as the system moves to a 12-year system; and (ii) a decline in new enrolments in 
grade 1 of approximately 10,000–20,000 students per year resulting from falling birth rates and 
an aging population. Enrolments are expected to stabilize in 2010 at around 5.3 million in 
grades 1–9. In 2004, 20.7% of the 9,757 general secondary schools were located in urban 
areas. Approximately 40% of basic education enrolments are in grades 1–4.  
 
4.  Public expenditure for education as a high priority sector has increased in real terms 
every year since 2000, and stood at 9.5% of gross domestic product in 2005. The share of basic 
education in total education expenditure has gone up from 45.5% to 50.3% over the past 5 
years, and is expected to rise further. Since 2004 the Government has accelerated efforts to 
refocus on basic education and to remedy many years of underfunding of the subsector. The 
National Program for Basic Education Development 2004–2009 was launched in 2004 with the 
key objective to urgently rehabilitate and upgrade the basic education system especially in rural 
areas, including physical plants, learning and teaching materials, computers, laboratory and 
sports equipment, and curriculum reform.  
 
5.  According  to  the  national  strategy  for  ICT  development  introduced  in  2002,  basic 
education is a priority area for the development of information and communications technology 
(ICT).1  In  2004  only  18%  of  general  secondary  schools  had  access  to  modern  personal 
computers and just 50% of schools had access to any form of computers including those made 
                                                 
1  Cabinet of Ministers, Uzbekistan. Resolution 30 May 2002. On Further Development of Computerization and 
Introduction of Information and Communication Technologies.

2 
in  the  Soviet  era.  Within  the  framework  of  the  National  Program  for  Basic  Education 
Development, the Government has launched a program to integrate ICT in basic education, with 
the provision of a 14+1 computer suite2 to every school in the country by 2009 and of internet 
connectivity to 35% of schools.  
 
B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
 
6.  Integrating ICT in basic education is an integral part of the Government’s long-term 
strategic objective of transforming the education system into one consistent with a market-
based  economy  in  the  21st  century.  While  ICT  promises  substantial  potential  gains,  a 
discussion of a number of key challenges follows.  
 
1.  Benefits of ICT Development in Basic Education   
 
7.  To meet the needs of the 21st century, which is increasingly knowledge and information 
based, basic education must produce graduates who can learn quickly and independently to 
ensure that the future workforce is sufficiently flexible to be able to apply old skills in new 
situations, and to acquire new skills and knowledge quickly when needed. Integrating ICT in 
schools will help to achieve this fundamental educational objective in the following five areas.  
  
8.  Ensuring Computer Competence as an Essential Basic Skill. ICT capability involves 
technical  and  cognitive  proficiency  to  access,  use,  develop,  create,  and  communicate 
information appropriately using ICT tools. Improved computer skills with basic ICT tools (word 
processing, spreadsheets, databases, presentation software, and other applications) increase 
student productivity; ICT skills are becoming a universal basic requirement. Currently, such 
skills are not learned in schools, as more than half of students have no excess to computers, 
and for those who do, computers are used only for theoretical informatics.  
 
9.  Promoting  Student-Centered  Learning  to  Improve  Learner  Engagement  and 
Motivation. ICT will support the change to student-centered learning, which is at the center of 
ongoing reforms in basic education. Despite years of efforts, didactic teaching methodologies 
and teacher-directed classrooms still dominate. A key advantage of ICT is to give students—
traditionally  on  the  passive  receiving  end—access  to  an  effective  means  of  acquiring, 
processing, and applying knowledge and information. Students enjoy using ICT because it 
provides alternative and user-friendly approaches to learning and the chance to develop the 
skills needed for the future. ICT facilitates students learning in groups, working with other 
learners, being creative, learning through challenging game-like activities, and setting clear 
personal  learning  goals.  ICT  use  also  stimulates  increased  teacher-student  interaction.  As 
students develop skills, they become more engaged with their own learning and thus more 
motivated. With ICT the curriculum can be tailored to a student’s individual learning needs and 
can be readily adapted to meet the needs of students with learning or physical disabilities.  
 
10.  Developing Higher Order Thinking Skills and Independent Learning Skills. ICT 
helps students to discriminate in their use of information and ICT tools, and to be appreciative 
and understanding of the role of ICT in learning. ICT allows students to investigate the real 
world more thoroughly, using up-to-date information and tools to build a broader and deeper 
knowledge base, and at the same time requires from learners higher levels of thinking and 
                                                 
2  This will give a computer student ratio of 1:42 on the current enrolment of 6.1 million. According to a Cabinet of 
Ministers’ decree dated 21 October 2004, the Government plans to supply computers to about 8,700 schools 
during 2005–2009, with the total number of computers supplied ranging from 100,000 to 140,000.

3 
problem  solving.  ICT  tools  can  be  used  to  support  application,  analysis,  synthesis,  and 
assessment  of  progress.  As  students  develop  their  own  independent  learning  styles,  they 
understand how they learn best and are well-prepared to become lifelong learners. They can 
seek information quickly and efficiently, and apply it in ways that are suitable to each new 
learning and employment context. 
 
11.  Enhancing Educational Attainment. With ICT, learners demonstrate improved skills 
and  understanding  by  applying  technology  purposefully  to  solve  problems,  analyze  and 
exchange information, develop ideas, create models, and control devices. Evidence shows that 
appropriately  used,  ICT  improves  learning  outcomes  through  enhanced  motivation  from 
students and teachers. As appropriate software is developed and applied in more subject areas, 
such enhanced attainment will become more widespread. Access to the internet offers sources 
of  e-learning  materials  to  improve  students’  background  knowledge  and  understanding  of 
curriculum subjects. The effective implementation of an ICT strategy will provide a learning 
management system, which can finely discriminate the nature of students’ learning needs and 
provide effective learning pathways to meet the needs of students of all abilities.   
 
12.  Contributing  to  the  Development  of  the  Knowledge  Economy.  ICT  capability  is 
much broader than acquiring a set of technical competencies in software applications. The most 
important feature in students’ use of ICT is their capacity to understand how the technology can 
solve problems and enable them to explore new dimensions of understanding. Successful 
players in the global economy are able to use technology to make productivity gains in existing 
industries and to maximize return on the new knowledge-based sectors. Over the long term, the 
Uzbek economy will increasingly need a highly educated and skilled workforce that can apply 
ICT  to  solve  problems;  model  solutions;  and  implement  strategies  that  are  efficient,  cost-
effective, and flexible. 
  
2.  Key Issues in ICT Development in Basic Education  
13.  While integrating ICT in learning and teaching promises substantial potential benefits, to 
realize these gains Uzbekistan must overcome considerable constraints over the medium and 
long term. These constraints are summarized here and discussed in detail in Appendix 3.  
 
14.  Teachers and ICT Use. Experience shows that teachers are a key to the success of ICT 
use in schools. To date, a large majority of general secondary teachers in Uzbekistan have 
never used a computer for any purpose. This is partly because of the policy of computer use 
only for the subject of informatics, and partly due to the lack of computers in schools. To turn 
teachers  into  champions  of  ICT  use  and  a  prime  source  of  support  for  students,  they 
themselves must first be familiar and comfortable with the technology, and become ICT adept in 
their own subject areas. This would require quality training of most of the 450,000 teachers 
within a relatively short time. The current in-service teacher training (INSETT) system would 
need significant improvement to fulfill this task (A brief review of the current teacher training 
system and issues is in Appendix 4). In particular, current in-service training is inflexible and 
ineffective, and is conducted at regional in-service teacher training institutes (RITTIs) located in 
oblast centers. Training is residential and infrequent with only 24 days of training for each 
teacher every 5 years. The system is particularly inconvenient for women, who account for over 
70% of the teaching force in basic education and are often unable to attend long residential

4 
courses.3 To provide effective support for ICT use, the existing INSETT system will need to be 
transformed to one that is closer to teachers, offers more frequent training (on a weekly or 
monthly basis), and acts as a center for interacting networks among teachers and schools. On 
the incentive side, the Government introduced a performance-based remuneration system in 
2003, and teachers’ salaries have increased substantially. Qualification for ICT use in subject 
areas and general management will need to be incorporated in the incentive system.  
 
15.  Learning Materials and ICT Use. Appropriate and adequate learning materials are a 
key condition for successful application of ICT in schools. At present, such materials are not 
available, and capacity is not adequate for developing such materials. The Government has 
made it a priority to develop e-textbooks. However, considerable efforts are needed to build this 
capacity,  which  is  basically  nonexistent.  In  developing  these  learning  materials,  wide 
participation must be encouraged, since this will require new concepts, skills, and talents that 
are not traditionally found in education circles. ICT will have a significant impact on the provision 
of  learning  and  teaching  materials  in  other  local  languages  of  instruction  (LOI)  because 
developing alternative language versions of materials in electronic form is much easier and 
cheaper than in print form. ICT will make the provision of local language materials more cost 
effective, make materials more accessible to students with other LOIs, and have a positive 
impact on the quality of their learning.  
 
16.  Curriculum and Assessment System and ICT Use. Introducing ICT in schools will 
help to accelerate long overdue reforms in the national curriculum, state education standards, 
and  national  student  assessment  system.  Despite  past efforts,  the  curriculum  content  has 
remained  overloaded.  This  leaves  little  time  for  interactive  and  student-oriented  teaching 
approaches  and  practices.  While  curriculum  reform  is  a  principal  component  of  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) supported Second Textbook Development Project (STDP)4 currently 
being implemented, ICT provision to schools will give impetus to the reform process, especially 
from the students, parents, and teachers, to create more space in the curriculum and syllabus 
for the effective use of ICT. This will complement the top-down approach used in curriculum 
reforms. The current student assessment system is time consuming (often using up to 50% of 
class time) and disliked widely by teachers and students. Widespread ICT provision will require 
improvements to develop an assessment system that is more practical and appropriate for a 
new curriculum, based on methodologies, criteria, and indicators for measuring and promoting 
modern learning and its outcomes. 
 
17.  School  E-Readiness  and  ICT  Service  and  Maintenance.  E-readiness  is  about 
meeting basic conditions that make effective use of ICT in schools possible. Aside from ICT-
qualified teachers, protocols and regulations must be developed and put in place for maintaining 
and properly using ICT facilities. Introducing ICT also requires proper physical conditions in 
schools. These include computer classrooms with proper wiring, security enhanced windows 
and doors, air-conditioning, and dust-reducing measures. School management must be strong 
supporters and key change agents for ICT use, for which training will be needed as a priority. At 
the same time, ICT will help to (i) enhance efficiency in using existing resources and reducing 
costs  (electronic  timetabling  and  electronic  textbook  ordering),  and  (ii)  improve  school 
management  capacity  (devolved  school  financing  and  computerized  information  systems). 
Adequate and timely service and maintenance at the school level is essential for ensuring 
                                                 
3  The fact that a large number of primary teachers are unqualified (about 50% by Ministry of Public Education 
estimates in 2002) and that the utilization rate of RITTIs is low at 60% is a strong indication of the ineffectiveness of 
the current INSETT system.  
4  ADB. 2004. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors on a Proposed Loan to the 
Republic of Uzbekistan for the Second Textbook Development Project. Manila.

5 
effective use of ICT facilities. Establishing an effective nationwide network for such services will 
need active and wide private sector participation. At present, these services exist mostly in 
oblast centers and urban areas, but are lacking in rural and remote areas. Effective demand for 
service and maintenance from schools is a key condition for establishing a nationwide service 
network.  
 
18.  Infrastructure Support and Power Supply. Access to the internet is an important part 
of  ICT  development.  Broadband  internet  connectivity  to  cluster  leader  schools  (CLSs)  will 
provide  the  best  support  for  schools.  The  process  of  upgrading  the  country’s 
telecommunications network to achieve widespread broadband access is to be completed in the 
next 2–3 years. In the interim, high-capacity connectivity will need to be provided to CLSs in 
phases where technically feasible. Prices for internet connections for schools will need to be 
adjusted to encourage internet use. Lack of reliable and predictable power supply during the 
school day is a major obstacle to computer use in many rural and remote areas. Unpaid 
electricity bills are a main reason for power cuts. Frequent and large-scale power surges are 
typical of all regions and load-shedding in many areas can range from 2–3 hours to the whole 
school day. Thus, ICT development in schools must consider appropriate policy and other 
measures to improve power supply especially to rural schools.   
 
19.  Financial Sustainability of ICT. ICT in basic education is costly. At current unit costs, 
with network-ready desktop personal computers5 and a target computer-student ratio of 1:42, 
equipping every basic education school will cost around $116 million. The annual replacement 
costs of this investment are around $23 million at current costs based on a 5-year replacement 
cycle. Operational costs (consumables, maintenance, and servicing) would add an estimated 
$10 million a year. Even without internet connectivity, the recurrent costs could amount to 
around $35 million per year, which is equivalent to 6.2% of the basic education budget. In 
addition  to  these  direct  recurrent  costs,  indirect  recurrent  costs  include  training  teachers, 
developing learning materials, providing technical and managerial support, and undertaking 
monitoring and evaluation (M&E) of progress. The total cost of ownership of integrating ICT in 
schools, even at the current planned moderate level, will be substantial. In addition, under 
current financing arrangements, schools have insufficient operation and maintenance (O&M) 
budgets. The requirement from ICT use would add substantially to this gap, which, unless fully 
provided by the Government, would seriously impair ICT development in schools.  
 
20.  Pro-Poor  ICT  Development.  The  Government  has  a  clear  pro-poor  policy  in  ICT 
development in schools, with the objective of reducing and bridging the internal digital divide. 
Already  funding  to  schools  varies  significantly  by  oblast.  Many  schools  rely  on  parental 
contributions to make up for shortfalls in O&M budgets. This represents a disproportionate 
burden on the poor. In general, schools in relatively affluent urban areas tend to have better 
teachers and conditions, and are better positioned to generate income to support ICT. These 
factors combined pose a serious challenge for the Government to provide the same access to 
schools in poor, rural, and remote areas as in urban areas and affluent centers.  
    
                                                 
5  A typical network-ready desktop personal computer also known as a “fat (thick) client” device does the majority of 
the application processing as well as storing applications software and data on its own hard disk. A fat client device 
can be used away from the network as a stand-alone device. In contrast, a non-network ready desktop terminal 
also known as the “thin client” network is one where the user, i.e., a student, can only access data and applications 
that are stored in the central server. A thin client device may process only keyboard input and screen output, 
leaving all application processing to the server. A thin client terminal generally does not have a hard drive and may 
well be unusable if disconnected from the network.

6 
3.  Government Strategy and Policy  
  
21.  Integrating ICT in schools is a key strategy of the Government to achieve its subsector 
objective of improving the quality and relevance of basic education, and to ensure equal access 
to all. Full integration of ICT in basic education will require an ICT-based curriculum, abundant 
learning materials, a majority of teachers adept at ICT use, adequate school conditions and 
physical infrastructure in place, provision of financial resources to cover the total cost of ICT 
ownership, and specifically designed pro-poor interventions from the public sector. At present, 
Uzbekistan has  embarked  on  the initial  phase  to  providing  full ICT  integration  in  schools. 
Cognizant of the tasks and the need to overcome considerable constraints, the Government has 
developed a draft strategy with ADB assistance to guide medium- and long-term implementation 
of its ICT in basic education program (Supplementary Appendix A).  
 
22.  The draft strategy focuses on long-term ICT development in basic education that will be 
financially  sustainable,  educationally  effective,  and  pro-poor.  To  achieve  this,  the  strategy 
proposes a phased approach, with the first phase in 2006–2010 and the second in 2011–2015. 
This approach prioritizes the limited resources available during the first phase to build a firm 
foundation for the long-term integration of ICT in basic education. Key to the first phase is to 
demonstrate real education benefits from ICT use in all schools. This, along with improvements 
in the broad financial and fiscal environments, will lay the foundation for larger scale and more 
integrated use of ICT in the second phase.  
 
23.  Central  to  successful  implementation  during  the  first  phase  is  the  establishment  of 
school clusters. Each cluster will contain an average of 11 schools so that 860 clusters will 
cover all schools in Uzbekistan. Each cluster will have a CLS whose role will be to lead all other 
schools in the cluster in activities relating to integrating ICT in teaching and learning. The school 
cluster concept is strategic—instead of spreading the limited financial and human resources 
evenly but thinly across all schools, the country will focus its resources on (i) establishing CLSs 
as champions and mentors for the use of ICT in the educational process, and strongholds for 
future ICT expansion; (ii) fostering the school cluster network into an effective decentralized 
delivery mechanism for, but not be limited to, teacher upgrading and ICT use in schools; and (iii) 
ensuring effective use of ICT in poor and remote schools including internet access.  
 
24.  In addition, ICT use in learning and teaching will be restricted to priority subject areas 
over a limited number of grades during the first phase. This will give more access time to ICT 
facilities per student and teacher, thus allowing real education benefits to accrue with limited 
financial resources. Further cost reduction solutions will be examined, in particular, the “thin 
client” option, which is promising to offer substantial savings in total cost of ownership. These 
measures combined will significantly strengthen the financial sustainability of the ICT policy.  
  
4.  Asian Development Bank Support for the Education Sector  
 
25.  Basic education is a key area of focus of ADB assistance to Uzbekistan, and ADB is the 
lead  external  development  partner  in  basic  education.  ADB’s  sector  strategy  in  education 
focuses on (i) supporting efforts to improve quality, relevance, and access to education; and (ii) 
enhancing  national  capacity  to  manage  sector  reforms.  Accordingly,  policy  dialogue  and 
assistance in basic education focus on addressing key issues and challenges of the subsector, 
with five loans approved by ADB since 1997.  
 
26.  ADB  assistance  to  the  sector  is  comprehensive,  including  (i)  establishing  a 
comprehensive policy framework for the sector, which is the focus of the Education Sector 
Development  Program  (ESDP);  (ii)  improving  governance,  education  financing,  and  sector

7 
reform management, which is woven into all projects; (iii) continuing curriculum and assessment 
improvement, which is a focus of the STDP; (iv) strengthening capacity of teachers and the 
teacher training system, which is a priority of both the ESDP and the Project; (v) meeting critical 
investment needs in learning materials especially textbooks, school libraries, and ICT facilities, 
which is a key activity in all projects; and (vi) supporting the poor and disadvantaged, which is a 
focus of all projects. Technical assistance from ADB has supported this effort, in particular in 
institution and capacity development. Appendix 5 summarizes the complementarity between the 
Project and ongoing ADB projects in basic education. 
 
27.  In close coordination with ongoing ADB projects in the education sector, the Project will 
serve as catalyst for changes in a number of key issues in basic education. In preparing the 
Project,  ADB  has  worked  closely  with  key  stakeholders  including  the  Ministry  of  Public 
Education  (MOPE)  and  Ministry  of  Finance  on  a  strategy  to  guide  implementation  of  the 
Government’s ICT program in basic education over the next 10 years (para. 21). The strategy 
preparation is based on a comprehensive analysis of key constraints and opportunities including 
financial sustainability, educational preparedness, infrastructural support, and equitable access.  
 
5.  Other External Support for the Education Sector 
 
28.  In  basic  education,  the  United  Nations  Children’s  Fund  and  the  United  Nations 
Educational,  Scientific,  and  Cultural  Organization  (UNESCO)  are  monitoring  learning 
achievements with results due by the end of 2005. This will be a useful step in addressing the 
current lack of data on learning outcomes. The United Nations Development Programme has 
assisted Uzbekistan in preparing a national strategy for ICT development, which identifies 
education  as  a  priority  sector  for  strategy  implementation.  The  United  States  Agency  for 
International Development has two ongoing projects: one is a pilot for strengthening learning 
and teaching, management, and participation in 100 schools; and the other is focusing on 
piloting ICT use in 60 schools. The latter has provided valuable experience in and lessons for 
effective and sustainable ICT use in schools. The World Bank is preparing its first education 
project,  which  will  support  learning  materials  development,  teacher  training,  community 
participation, and school management. Some bilateral partners provide support in vocational 
and higher education. The People’s Republic of China recently concluded an agreement to 
provide a loan of $19 million to Uzbekistan in support of ICT in basic education. The Project was 
prepared in close coordination with all other external agencies active in the education sector. 
ADB has initiated regular aid coordination meetings for the education sector, which will provide 
a forum to discuss harmonization measures in the sector. A development coordination matrix is 
in Appendix 6.  
 
6.  Lessons Learned  
 
29.  Appendix 7 summarizes lessons learned and how they are incorporated in the project 
design. A key lesson learned in projects involving ICT development in schools, both from ADB 
and elsewhere, is the importance of development of the broad supporting environment. This 
includes capacity building for teachers and staff, e-readiness of schools, e-learning materials 
development, and appropriate curriculum adjustments. Without, or with insufficient, essential 
support, the full potential benefits from ICT in schools will not be realized. These lessons are 
supported by a recent UNESCO report on ICT experiences in Asia and the Pacific, which 
stresses the importance of a balanced approach combining hardware provision with appropriate

8 
support  services.6  These  lessons  are  reflected  in  the  project  design.  Capacity  building  of 
teachers and staff and the institutional development of the in-service teaching training system 
make up a key component of the Project to impart long-lasting benefits beyond the use of ICT. 
E-readiness is a condition for installation of ICT facilities in schools; the Project will provide 
grants to encourage and stimulate development of e-learning materials especially in the Uzbek 
language. For curriculum support, the Project will coordinate closely with the ongoing STDP, 
which has curriculum reform as a major component.  
 
30.  The  importance  of  financial  sustainability  is  another  major  lesson  learned  in  most 
projects for ICT development in education, and has major implications for equitability of access. 
Early projects tended to underestimate the costs of O&M for ICT. Recent projects in other 
countries have relied on parental contributions or other income-generating activities at schools 
to cover these costs. While enthusiasm about ICT use is widespread among students, parents, 
and teachers, parental contributions for ICT use would add a great burden especially for those 
who are less able to afford it. Similarly, using school ICT facilities to generate income tends to 
work in affluent and urban areas, while schools in poor and remote areas would end up being 
disadvantaged. Instead, built on comprehensive financial and economic analysis, the Project 
seeks full funding of the total cost from the Government to ensure sustainability and equitable 
access and use of ICT by the poor.  
 
III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
31.  The impact of the Project is improved quality, relevance, and equitable access of basic 
education for all students, including students in poor and remote areas. The outcome of the 
Project is the improvement of learning outcomes through ICT use in priority subject areas in 
grades  5–9  in  project  schools  with  a  pro-poor  focus.  These  priority  subject  areas  are 
mathematics,  sciences,  history,  and  languages,  in  addition  to  informatics.  A  design  and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
B.  Outputs 
 
32.  The Project comprises four components: (i) establishment of school clusters for ICT, (ii) 
teacher and staff development for ICT, (iii) learning materials development, and (iv) capacity 
building and management support. 
 
1.  Establishment of School Clusters for ICT 
33.  This component will develop an operational national network of 860 school clusters, 
covering all 9,757 schools in Uzbekistan; each cluster will be led by a CLS.7 The Project will 
provide  appropriate  ICT  facilities/connectivity  to  CLSs.  The  Government  will  provide  ICT 
facilities to other schools in the clusters as part of its ICT in basic education program.  
 
34.  As the strategic focus for investment in ICT hardware, connectivity, and training in ICT 
teaching and learning, professional development, and management skills, the CLSs will (i)

9 
provide an efficient delivery system to all schools for e-learning materials and information; (ii) 
operate as centers for all education development activities within the clusters; (iii) provide 
pedagogical, technical, and management support to all schools in the cluster; (iv) provide the 
institutional structure for the rapid development of a decentralized and effective INSETT; (v) 
coordinate with learning resource centers (LRCs) and the new school libraries, both being 
developed  under  other  ADB-supported  projects;  (vi)  undertake  pilot  testing  and  research 
initiatives related to ICT integration in basic education; and (vii) provide the vehicle for effective 
M&E of school ICT developments. Supplementary Appendix B outlines the role, responsibilities, 
and selection criteria of the CLSs. 
 
35.  The CLSs will be equipped with standard “fat client” networks under the Project because 
they will need greater technical capacity and flexibility to fulfill their lead role in the clusters. 
These include pedagogically essential peripherals including data projectors, digital cameras, 
printers, and audiovisual equipment. Proposed specifications for hardware and peripherals are 
in Supplementary Appendix C. Each CLS will be supplied with one additional free-standing 
computer for school management/administration with a set of basic software, including (i) the 
United Nations Children’s Fund school-based education management information system, (ii) 
textbook ordering software (from the STDP), (iii) school timetabling software, and (iv) basic 
school accounting software. The CLSs will have internet and intranet connectivity to ensure that 
they receive a wide range of e-learning materials. All the e-learning materials will be distributed 
by the CLSs to all the schools in the cluster. Supplementary Appendix D provides an outline of 
the phased manner in which connectivity will be extended to all CLSs. 
 
36.  Power  cuts  inhibit  the  full  use  of  ICT  hardware,  especially  in  rural  areas.  The 
Government will take appropriate and timely measures to ensure reliable power supply to all 
CLSs, and to all schools based on the experience with the CLSs. Reliable power supply will be 
a condition for ICT installation. Adequate financing for O&M costs is identified as the key to 
ensuring supply of consumables, and adequate servicing and maintenance, and thus to project 
success. The Government will provide adequate and timely O&M allocations for all schools with 
ICT  facilities,  including  CLSs,  to  ensure  effective  usage  and  sustainability.  The  Project  is 
expected to create effective demand for ICT maintenance services through the availability of 
school-based budgets, and will improve service quality through standard servicing contracts 
between schools and service providers.8  
 
2.  Teacher and Staff Development for ICT  
 
37.  This component will build the capacity of teachers and staff for improving teaching and 
learning through ICT use. This will require (i) creation of trained trainers and development of 
specially  designed  course  modules  in  the  RITTIs  in  high  priority  subject  areas  for  ICT 
development in basic education and across the curriculum; (ii) immediate training in essential 
skills provided first to CLSs and then to every school with ICT facilities; and (iii) strengthening of 
the delivery of a decentralized system for continuous professional development (CPD) for all 
school staff.  
 
38.  Integrating  ICT  in  basic  education  will  create  new  demands  on  staff  and  on  the 
continuous upgrading of their professional skills. The training will cover (i) ICT skills in school

network management,9 (ii) subject-based courses for RITTI lecturers and teachers as future 
trainers on the use of ICT across the curriculum, (iii) use of ICT in school administration, and (iv) 
introduction of performance management and CPD for teachers. The Project will use the cluster 
approach to bring in-service training to local areas through the introduction of CPD, firstly in 
ICT-related  training  but  thereafter  in  the  full  range  of  professional  training  and  upgrading 
requirements. Bringing the existing in-service training system closer to schools and making it 
more accessible to teachers and thus more effective will be a key to the success of capacity 
building in support of ICT use. This will be accomplished through the CLSs, which will provide 
the enabling institutional structure for the system. The Project will train 220 staff from the RITTIs 
and 560 staff from the LRCs in ICT-related skills, and will provide priority training to the CLSs 
and LRCs comprising 1,720 school network managers/ICT coordinators, 4,300 subject teachers 
in  the  use  of  ICT  in  priority  subjects,  and  1,720  administrators  and  specialists  in  school 
administration  management  and  CPD  for  teachers.  During  2006–2010,  81,000  teachers, 
technicians, administrators, and school network managers from the 8,900 non-CLS schools will 
be trained in the specialist skills required to integrate ICT into the basic education system.  
 
39.  The Project will be closely coordinated with the ESDP. A focus of the ESDP is to 
strengthen the RITTIs’ capacity in distance education delivery. Where possible, the INSETT 
course modules developed to support ICT in basic education under the Project will be adapted 
for distance education delivery. Enhancing CPD for teachers using the CLSs will require a 
system of performance management, which will be developed and made operational during the 
first year after loan effectiveness. The system will (i) identify annual staff needs for CPD, and (ii) 
link training completed to performance targets and the remuneration system.  
 
3.  Learning Materials Development for ICT 
 
40.  This component will develop appropriate learning materials in Uzbek and other local 
LOIs for priority subjects and grades, and will focus on developing local capacity for such 
purposes. This will require (i) training in learning materials development, (ii) development of e-
materials in Uzbek and other LOIs, (iii) competitive award of grants to encourage competition 
and quality material development, and (iv) localization and translation of already successful 
software from other countries.  
 
41.  ICT use across the curriculum requires the development of e-materials, including (i) 
generic software applications such as spreadsheets and databases, (ii) web/intranet-based 
materials,  (iii)  e-books,  and  (iv)  subject-specific  educational  software.  These  materials  will 
support  teachers  in  the  use  of  ICT  and  help  students  to  work  independently.  Other  non-
computer  based  ICT  materials  including  DVDs  (digital  video  disks)  and  other  audiovisual 
equipment  are  also  helpful  in  learning  and  teaching.  For  most  schools  without  direct 
internet/intranet connections during the first phase of ICT development these materials can be 
provided on CDs (compact disks), or downloaded and cached onto school servers. A portal will 
be developed at MOPE for the intranet network within 9 months of loan effectiveness.  
 
42.  Training  in  e-materials  development  skills  will  be  provided  through  the  RITTIs. 
Specifically,  200  staff  will  be  trained  in  licensing,  localizing,  and  translation  techniques  of 
existing software in other languages and in developing original materials. The RITTIs will offer 
courses in software development to 400 teachers and to private sector specialists on a cost-
recovery basis. The Project will award software development grants competitively, in close

coordination with the STDP school library material development grant. The grants will initially 
concentrate  on  the  adaptation  and  translation  into  local  languages  of  existing  educational 
software with a proven track record of effectiveness.  
 
4.  Capacity Building and Management Support  
 
43.  This component will ensure project sustainability and effective implementation through 
the development of appropriate policy and support for the introduction of ICT to basic education 
and effective project implementation.  
 
44.  First, support will be provided for effective financial planning through the development of 
annual financial plans and budgets, including adequate annual operational budgets to support 
effective ICT use in schools and the determination of realistic ICT replacement and O&M 
budgets for wider financial planning purposes. Second, support will be provided for targeted 
research/pilot  testing  activities,  including  (i)  income  generation  opportunities  (e.g.,  rural 
telecenters for use by communities), (ii) decentralized school financing, (iii) use of ICT for 
students  with  special  education  needs,  (iv)  cost  comparisons  of  “thin”  and  “fat  client” 
technologies, and (v) alternative approaches to school connectivity particularly for schools in 
rural and remote areas with difficult access. Well-designed pilot testing and research will provide 
important  insights  for  future  policy  and  the  development  of  new  approaches  to  existing 
problems. Third, the component will design and implement a system of M&E, which will provide 
valuable feedback on project progress against objectives and provide the basis for the design of 
successor projects and the formation of second phase ICT policy. Fourth, support will be given 
for a national publicity campaign to ensure that all stakeholders and the wider communities are 
fully informed about the Government’s plans for ICT development in basic education in general 
and the Project in particular. Staff development and pilot projects are outlined in Supplementary 
Appendix E. 
  
C.  Special Features 
 
45.  Pro-Poor Design. The Project’s poverty focus is reflected in several major aspects of its 
design. First, about 70% of project schools will be in poor or rural areas where the majority of 
the poor of the country reside. Second, through the school clusters, the Project will help ensure 
access to internet connection, and provide technical and pedagogical support for effective ICT 
use  to  all  schools  in  the  country  including  those  in  rural  and  remote  areas.  Third,  the 
Government is committed to providing adequate and timely financing for O&M, replacement, 
and other related costs for supporting ICT use in all schools as well as the initial investment and 
future replacement costs. These commitments are reflected in the project assurances and will 
benefit the poor disproportionately since affordability issues are a greater concern for the poor. 
Fourth, the Project will help to improve power supply to schools. Schools in poor and remote 
areas will benefit the most, not only from ICT use, but also for general lighting and heating 
purposes, as these schools currently experience less reliable power supply. Finally, the Project 
will pilot test (i) ICT to improve learning and teaching for children with special education needs, 
which is a priority of the Government; and (ii) technologies that will improve connectivity for 
schools in remote areas.  
 
46.  Integrated  and  Participatory  Approach  to  Project  Design  and  Implementation. 
Given the complexity of the issues involved, the successful integration of ICT in basic education 
will  require  a  comprehensive  approach.  The  Project  is  based  on  a  national  strategy  that 
addresses  key  issues  and  constraints  systematically,  including  financial  sustainability, 
educational preparedness, infrastructure support, and equitable access to ICT. The strategy

12 
proposes a phased approach to ensure medium- and long-term success in ICT use in schools. 
The Project emphasizes institution and capacity development through the establishment of 
school clusters and the improvement of CPD for teachers. The school clusters will provide an 
effective mechanism for further decentralization and empowerment in basic education beyond 
the use of ICT, and the improvement of INSETT will bring beneficial changes to the system in 
addition to ICT use. The project design has benefited significantly from a participatory approach. 
Apart from MOPE and other agencies of the central Government, consultations were held at all 
14 oblast (province) centers, visits were made to over 30 of the 199 raions (districts), and over 
60  schools  and  makhallas  (communities),  where  over  180  focus  group  discussions  with 
teachers, parents, and students were conducted. In addition, six consultation workshops were 
held at the central government level besides regular consultations with individual departments of 
key  ministries.  Participation  will  also  be  a  key  characteristic  of  project  implementation.  In 
particular, the school clusters will enable and encourage more interactions among teachers, 
parents, students, and local communities. Key issues related to integrating ICT in schools, and 
the special features of the Project are described in Supplementary Appendix F.

E.  Financing Plan 
 
48.  The Government has requested a loan of $30.0 million equivalent from ADB’s Special 
Funds resources to help finance the Project. The loan will have a 32-year term, including a 
grace period of 8 years, with an interest charge of 1% per annum during the grace period and 
1.5% per annum thereafter. ADB will finance 70% of the total cost of the Project, including 96% 
of the foreign exchange cost of $25.1 million and 29% of the local cost. The Government will 
finance $1.0 million of foreign exchange cost and $12.0 million equivalent of local costs (Table 
2). Details of the financing plan are in Appendix 8.

F.  Implementation Arrangements  
 
1.  Project Management 
 
49.  MOPE will be the Executing Agency. Project management will consist of (i) a project 
steering committee (PSC), (ii) a project director, and (iii) a project implementation unit (PIU). 
The  PSC,  to  be  appointed  by  the  Cabinet  of  Ministers,  will  be  the  decision-making  body 
responsible for overall project implementation and coordination. The project director, to be 
appointed by the PSC, will provide general guidance to the PIU in accordance with decisions 
made by the PSC, arrange the quarterly PSC meetings, present quarterly reports to the PSC, 
and ensure coordination of project implementation within MOPE. Given MOPE’s experience 
with ADB project implementation accumulated since 1998 and the recent successful completion 
of the Basic Education Textbook Development Project,10  financial management arrangements 
of MOPE are satisfactory for purposes of implementation of the Project.  
 
50.  As a part of its efforts to strengthen project implementation for more effective use of 
public resources, MOPE is in the process of rationalizing project management in the education 
sector. Accordingly, the Project will integrate its management with that of ongoing projects in 
basic  education  to  reduce  transaction  costs  and  maximize  economic  efficiency  in  project 
implementation. In particular, the PSC for the Project will be integrated into one common PSC 
for the ESDP and STDP. Members of the existing PSCs are from the Cabinet of Ministers, 
MOPE, Ministry of Finance, and other agencies; participation may be adjusted to meet the 
needs of the Project. The PSC will also consider appointing the project director for the ESDP 
and STDP as the project director for the Project. 
 
51.  The PIU will be responsible for day-to-day project management, including procurement 
and recruitment, staff development, finance and accounting, and monitoring and evaluation; as 
well as preparing detailed project implementation plans, annual reports, and quarterly progress 
reports to submit to the PSC, the project director, and ADB. The PIU will have 6–8 full-time staff 
with expertise in these areas. To ensure timely start-up of project implementation, MOPE will 
                                                 
10  ADB. 1997. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors on a Proposed Loan to the 
Republic of Uzbekistan for the Basic Education Textbook Development Project.  Manila.

14 
appoint  a  project  manager,  who  will  be  responsible  for  day-to-day  coordination  of  project 
activities. The PIU will be established in accordance with a government decision related to the 
establishment and financing of this PIU, which will be covered by retroactive financing (para. 
57). The PIU will be established in the same premises as the PIUs of the two ongoing projects, 
and will coordinate closely with them across PIU functions, including sharing of staff where 
feasible.  Eventual  consideration  will  be  given  to  measures  to  further  harmonize  project 
management. A project management chart is in Appendix 9. 
 
2.  Implementation Period 
 
52.  The Project will be implemented over 5 years, from 1 January 2006 to 31 December 
2010. A project implementation schedule is in Appendix 10. 
 
3.  Procurement 
 
53.  The Project will procure (i) standard packages of ICT hardware and peripherals, and 
related furniture and other equipment for 860 CLSs; (ii) non-computer based learning materials 
and  equipment  including  audiovisual  sets;  and  (iii)  furniture  and  computers  for  office  and 
administrative use. ADB loan-financed goods and services will be procured following ADB’s 
Guidelines for Procurement. Procurement of largest value will be for ICT hardware, which may 
be distributed into several packages each larger than $1 million to allow proper sequencing of 
installation of ICT equipment in schools.11 Goods and services will be procured by international 
competitive  bidding  where  the  cost  is  valued  at  more  than  $1  million  equivalent,  or  by 
international shopping where the cost is valued from $100,000 to $1 million equivalent. Direct 
purchase may be applicable for goods and services valued at less than $100,000 equivalent. 
Procurement of furniture and the development of software and e-materials valued at less than 
$0.5 million per contract may follow local competitive bidding procedures acceptable to ADB. 
The Government will finance and undertake necessary civil works, in particular to rehabilitate 
and upgrade computer classrooms. Minimum criteria to be met by a school prior to installation 
of ICT equipment have been agreed.  
 
54.  The Government has been advised that ADB policy requires the borrower (including 
beneficiaries of ADB loans), bidders, suppliers, and contractors under ADB-financed contracts, 
to observe the highest standards of ethics during the procurement and execution of such 
contracts. Indicative procurement packages are in Appendix 11. 
 
4.  Consulting Services 
 
55.  The Project will require 212 person-months of consulting services, consisting of 52.5 
person-months  of  international  and  159.5  person-months  of  domestic  consulting.  Areas  of 
expertise required include education reform and decentralization, software development, ICT in 
basic education, training, CPD, school networking, and pilot project design and evaluation. 
International consultants will be engaged through a firm in association with domestic consultants 
using quality and cost-based selection with full technical proposals in accordance with ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants. PIU staff will be recruited separately using arrangements

equipment, sequencing of procurement of ICT equipment is appropriate.

15 
satisfactory to ADB. Outline terms of reference for international and domestic consultants are in 
Appendix 12.  
 
5.  Disbursement Arrangements 
 
56.  The proposed loan will be disbursed in accordance with ADB’s Loan Disbursement 
Handbook. If Government funds are first used for eligible expenditures, ADB's reimbursement 
procedure will be applied. The Government requested the establishment of an imprest account, 
with a ceiling of $150,000, to expedite loan disbursement. Statement of expenditure procedure 
will be used to liquidate/replenish the imprest account and to reimburse eligible expenditures 
that do not exceed $20,000 per payment.  
 
6.  Retroactive Financing and Advanced Procurement Action 
57.  The Government has requested ADB to provide retroactive financing to cover the PIU 
operational expenditures from 26 August 2005 (completion date of loan appraisal) up to the loan 
effectiveness date. The Government has also requested advance procurement action for ICT 
equipment for the 860 CLSs and for office equipment and a vehicle for the PIU. The advance 
action will be undertaken in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement. The total 
amount under retroactive financing is estimated at not more than $100,000. The Government 
was advised that ADB approval of advance action and retroactive financing does not commit 
ADB to financing the Project. 
 
7.  Accounting, Auditing, and Reporting 
 
58.  MOPE will maintain separate accounts for project components financed by ADB and the 
Government,  and  will  prepare  financial  statements  according  to  international  accounting 
standards.  MOPE  will  have  the  project  accounts  and  related  financial  statements  audited 
annually by independent auditors with adequate qualification, knowledge, and experience in 
international accounting practices acceptable to ADB. Certified copies of the audited project 
accounts and financial statements, as well as the auditor’s reports including a separate audit 
opinion on the use of the imprest account and statement of expenditure procedures will be 
submitted to ADB within 6 months after the end of each financial year. The Government was 
advised  of  ADB’s  requirement  for  the  timely  submission  of  audited  project  accounts  and 
financial statements, including the suspension of disbursements in case of noncompliance. 
 
59.  MOPE will prepare and submit to ADB quarterly reports in English and in a format 
acceptable to ADB on progress made and problems encountered during the period under 
review, the steps taken or proposed to remedy problems encountered during the quarter, and 
the proposed activities and expected progress during the following period. Within 3 months of 
physical completion of the Project, MOPE will submit a project completion report to ADB to 
facilitate postevaluation of the Project. The project completion report will provide details about 
implementation, costs, benefits, and other information requested by ADB.  
 
8.  Project Performance Monitoring and Evaluation 
 
60.  In addition to targets specified in the project framework, systematic monitoring and 
evaluation will be specifically developed and undertaken during project implementation. For this 
purpose a set of indicators for monitoring and evaluating project performance in relation to its 
impact, outcome, and outputs will be agreed upon prior to loan negotiations (Appendix 13). The 
establishment of the baseline values of the indicators will be one of the first activities after

16 
project implementation begins and the PIU is established. Since the first CLSs are unlikely to 
come onstream until the third quarter of 2006, this will allow sufficient time to design and 
conduct the baseline study and establish definitive indicators. Monitoring indicators will be 
measured and reported on annually during project implementation. Comments and findings on 
these indicators will be incorporated into quarterly reports to ADB. In addition to indicators for 
implementation  monitoring,  indicators  for  project  evaluation  will  be  measured  at  project 
completion  and  3  years  afterward.  Where  feasible  and  appropriate,  these  data  should  be 
disaggregated  by  poverty  rating,  gender,  LOI,  and  location  (oblast/raion  and 
remote/rural/urban). At project inception, completion, and 3 years after completion, MOPE will 
submit to ADB a report that summarizes the key findings of monitoring and evaluation of 
changes that occurred in the 3 preceding years. The PIU will be responsible for monitoring 
project activities using data and feedback from the RITTIs, LRCs, oblast and raion education 
departments, oblast finance departments, CLSs including teachers, students and parents, and 
domestic and international consultant reports.  
 
9.  Project Review 
 
61.  The Project will be reviewed at least twice a year. In addition, given that much of the 
research  and  pilot  testing  will  be  carried  out  during  the  first  years  of  implementation, 
comprehensive reviews of project performance will be conducted at the end of the first and third 
years  of  implementation.  The  first  comprehensive  review  will  focus  on  the  results  and 
implications of research and pilot testing, as well as the effectiveness of the implementation 
arrangements.  The  second  (midterm)  review  will  (i)  review  the  scope,  design,  and 
implementation arrangements of the Project; (ii) identify any changes required since the time of 
project appraisal; (iii) assess progress of project implementation against performance indicators; 
(iv) review progress made by the Government in ensuring financial sustainability of introducing 
ICT  in  basic  education;  and  (v)  if  necessary,  recommend  changes  in  the  design  or 
implementation arrangements.  
 
10.  Anticorruption Measures 
 
62.  The  Mission  explained  ADB’s  anticorruption  policy  to  Government  officials  and 
highlighted paras. 1.06 to 1.08 of ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement on issues concerning fraud 
and corruption. The Government agreed to include the relevant sections of ADB’s anticorruption 
policy in all documents and contracts during bidding for and implementation of the Project. 
 
IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
 
A.   Project Benefits and Beneficiaries 
 
63.  Direct Beneficiaries. The Project will directly benefit students in grades 5–9 in the 860 
CLSs, totaling 540,000 during the life of the Project. The benefits will come from the improved 
learning  and  teaching  conditions  resulting  from  the  provision  and  application  of  ICT  in 
classrooms and internet connections. Direct beneficiaries will also include 7,740 teachers in 
CLSs, 63,200 teachers in non-CLSs, 1,720 CLS school management staff, 17,800 management 
staff in non-CLSs, 220 RITTI lecturers, and 600 local language e-materials developers, whose 
skills will improve by the targeted training to be provided under the Project. Given the proposed 
central role of the CLSs in the school system, all students and teachers will benefit from the 
Project, albeit to a less intensive degree than those identified here. This would amount to about 
6 million students and 200,000 teachers during 2006–2010. Finally, the Project will seek to

17 
extend ICT facilities in schools to the wider community, from which an estimated 1 million 
households in mostly poorer rural areas will benefit.  
 
64.  Poverty and Social Development Impact. The Project will have a direct beneficial 
impact on about 165,000 poor students in grades 5–9 enrolled in the 860 CLSs during 2006–
2011.12 Specific pro-poor measures of the Project include (i) ensuring about 70% of the 860 
CLSs from rural and poor areas; (ii) improving power supply to schools to ensure proper 
working of the ICT facilities installed as well as for general lighting and heating purposes in 
winter;13 and (iii) developing stakeholder awareness of the needs of vulnerable children and pilot 
demonstration on the development of e-learning materials and teacher trainings. By providing 
ICT facilities and internet connectivity, the Project will benefit the poor and help to bridge the 
internal digital divide. The Project will address the issue of increasing parental contributions to 
schools, which burdens the poor disproportionately, by ensuring that no parental contributions 
will be required for ICT use in schools. Finally, the Project will benefit an estimated 1 million 
households in poor and rural communities through open access to ICT facilities in schools.14  
 
65.  The Project will provide an assessment of gender stereotyping through analysis of e-
materials content and identify appropriate strategies for improving the presentation of gender 
roles and issues. The Project will ensure that girls and boys have equal access to all required 
learning e-materials and ICT. The improved INSETT system that is closer to schools and more 
flexible will benefit at least 28,000 women teachers who account for over 70% of the teaching 
force in the CLSs, with a far greater number of women teachers in the school system who will 
benefit during the life of the Project. A summary poverty reduction and social strategy is in 
Appendix 14.  
 
66.  Educational Benefits. The main educational benefits from the introduction of ICT into 
basic  education  will  be  a  fundamental  shift  to  student  centered  learning  and  teaching 
methodologies. This will be reflected in (i) the link between integrated ICT use in the school 
curriculum  and  improved  student  performance  in  the  priority  subjects  for  ICT  use;  (ii)  the 
development of skills and competencies (as opposed to factual knowledge accumulation) and 
the development of higher order thinking skills; (iii) increased student responsibility for their own 
work,  enhanced  student  research  capacity,  and  greater  individual  learning;  (iv)  enhanced 
students’ motivation; and (v) increased relevance of education due to familiarity with information 
and computers. These combined will have a positive impact on the overall system to produce 
graduates  with  the  ability  to  meet  working  life  challenges  in  the  21st  century  where  the 
workforce  will  be  required  to  have  increasingly  advanced  skills  in  information  access, 
management, processing, and usage. 
 
67.   The  Project  will  significantly  improve  the  effectiveness  of  the  system  for  CPD  for 
teachers. In particular, the establishment of school clusters and the close working relationship 
required between the existing RITTIs and CLSs under the Project will make the content of CPD 
more relevant and its delivery more effective. The Project will also lay the foundation for the 
planned second phase of ICT development after 2010, which is expected to lead to rapid gains 
in learning outcomes.
