68.  Financial and Economic Analyses. The most significant economic benefit will come 
from (i) increases in future earnings of school graduates with better education attainment and 
information literacy, and (ii) better utilization of the 20% of teacher time currently allocated for 
professional  development.  Under  plausible  assumptions,  extra  earnings  of  about  600,000 
graduates could reach $30 million a year. The collaboration between cluster schools will utilize 
the allocated CPD day more fully. This would be equivalent to $16.1 million a year assuming a 
50% effective recovery rate of the teachers’ salaries for the CPD day that is lost under the 
current system. Quantifiable benefits will also come from each of the four project components 
by  reducing  costs  or  increasing  efficiency  in  existing  expenditures.  The  total  quantifiable 
economic benefit of the Project is estimated at $54.8 million per year. The net present value 
(NPV) of the project impact under the high case scenario of economic benefit utilization is $69.1 
million with an economic internal rate of return (EIRR) of 43% from 2006–2015. In the medium 
case scenario, the NPV is $29.9 million with an EIRR of 23%, while the NPV in the low case 
scenario is minus $17.6 million with an EIRR of 6%. While the low case scenario indicates the 
potential  risk  of  the  Project,  the medium  and  high case  scenarios  highlight  the  significant 
benefits of the Project with accelerated rate of economic benefit utilization. In both the high and 
low case scenarios, the total Government commitment to externally funded projects in education 
is deemed affordable and sustainable. The economic and financial analysis is in Supplementary 
Appendix G. 
 
69.  Environmental and Social Safeguards. The Project will carry out minor repairs and 
rehabilitation of existing school buildings and facilities to be funded by the Government, with no 
land acquisition required, or negative environmental or resettlement impact. The Project will 
enhance access and equity for education directly for about 45,000 students using other LOIs in 
the CLSs through equal access to ICT facilities and the creation of learning materials under the 
Project. Development of e-learning materials will help reduce production costs of textbooks in 
other LOIs thus benefiting the students by increasing the availability of learning materials.  
 
B.   Risks 
 
70.  The Project faces three major types of risks.  
 
71.  Risks Related to the Adoption of New Technology. Using ICT in schools is new; 
more than 50% of schools have never had access to computers. The risks of inadequate and 
inappropriate use of ICT as well as mismanagement of the facilities will be high. These risks will 
be mitigated by extensive capacity building for teachers and school management to ensure 
intended use and impact of ICT in schools. 
 
72.  Infrastructure and Logistical Risks. For the effective use of ICT in schools, the Project 
will  require  a  number  of  basic  infrastructure  and  logistical  conditions  to  be  met,  including 
appropriate  classroom  facilities  with  security  arrangements,  power  supply,  internet/intranet 
connectivity,  and  services  and  maintenance.  These  concerns  are  addressed  through 
covenanted assurances. 
 
73.  Financial Sustainability Risks. Throughout the design of the Project, the financial 
implications of the integration of ICT have been carefully reviewed and extensive consultations 
held with the Government to ensure the Project and the Government’s plans for integrating ICT 
in basic education are financially sustainable. The Project addresses these concerns through (i) 
covenants on adequate and timely budget provision for O&M and replacement costs; (ii) piloting 
of low cost “thin-client” solutions; and (iii) a strong focus on financial sustainability during project 
reviews, including the midterm review.

19 
V.  ASSURANCES 
 
A.  Specific Assurances 
 
74.  In  addition  to  the  standard  assurances,  the  Government  has  given  the  following 
assurances, which will be incorporated in the legal documents. 
 
75.  Government Counterpart Funding. The Government will allocate annually, in a timely 
manner, adequate funding in the budget for the counterpart funding specified by the Project, 
and will provide ADB with information on such allocations annually. 
  
76.  Financing  for  Sustainable  ICT  Use  in  All  Schools.  The  Government  will  make 
adequate annual budget allocations in the medium-term budgetary framework satisfactory to 
ADB  for  ICT  use  in  all  schools  to  cover  hardware  investments,  O&M  costs  including 
consumables, servicing, maintenance, electricity, cost of equipment replacement, and cost of in-
service teacher training, by (i) adopting a regulation describing operational and strategic goals 
for all schools and budget allocations assigned to them; (ii)  establishing a quarterly reporting 
system showing the receipts and use of funds intended for ICT use by all schools; (iii) allocating 
in  the  medium-term  budgetary  framework  an  amount  satisfactory  to  ADB  to  cover  the 
replacement costs of the equipment; and (iv) providing information on an annual basis to ADB 
on items (i), (ii), and (iii) before the state budget is finalized. 
 
77.  Connectivity  for  CLSs.  The  Government  will  provide  (i)  reliable  connectivity  to  all 
CLSs; (ii) technical specifications related to connectivity before each contract package of ICT 
equipment financed by ADB is finalized; and (iii) adequate financing in a timely manner to cover 
the installation and operational costs of internet/intranet connectivity for all CLSs by adopting 
the same mechanism as indicated in para. 76, items (i), (ii), and (iv).  
 
78.  Pricing Adjustment to Encourage Internet Connection. The Government through 
MOPE will initiate discussions with Uzbektelecom with a view to successfully reducing prices for 
internet connections for project schools within 6 months of loan effectiveness. 
 
79.  Incentives for Professional Development for Teachers in ICT Use. The Government 
through MOPE will integrate teachers’ professional development in ICT use into the improved 
incentive system for teachers. This incentive will recognize and reward teachers who have 
received  ICT  training  with  certification.  The  Government  through  MOPE  will  propose  such 
incentive schemes by 31 December 2006 for piloting starting in 2007, and will inform and 
update ADB on the progress of such piloting.  
 
80.  ICT Installation in All Schools. The Government through MOPE will ensure that oblast 
and raion staff will rigorously apply the national guidelines for ICT installation prior to ICT 
installation to ensure that all schools are ready to receive ICT installations. Specifically, no 
school should be supplied with an ICT installation unless a suitable ICT classroom is available, 
with necessary security arrangements and reliable power supply, and at least one staff member 
has training in the management of hardware and the school network. The Government through 
MOPE will semiannually update ADB on progress of the Government program of ICT provision 
to schools.  
 
81.  Priority  for  Rehabilitation  of  CLSs.  The  Government  will  ensure  that  school 
rehabilitation and refurbishment of computer rooms, including the safe rewiring of premises, 
provision of adequate climate control (air-conditioning and dust-control measures), and security 
arrangements to CLSs will be completed according to the minimum criteria agreed between the

20 
Government and ADB, and Government regulations, including Cabinet of Ministers’ resolution 
321 of 9 June 2004. The Government will ensure that the rehabilitation of schools will be carried 
out in a timely manner to ensure expeditious installation of ICT equipment in the CLSs.  
 
82.  Rehabilitation of CLSs. The Government will ensure that rehabilitation of CLSs will 
involve only minor civil works with no negative environmental impact. The Government will 
ensure that the rehabilitation will not entail any land acquisition or resettlement.  
 
83.  Power Supply to All Schools. The Government through MOPE, Ministry of Finance, 
and the State Joint-Stock Company UZBEKENERGO will, within 6 months of loan effectiveness, 
take appropriate measures satisfactory to ADB to ensure reliable power supply to all CLSs. This 
will be treated as a pilot for reliable power supply to all schools. The midterm review of the 
Project will assess the piloting of CLSs. Based on the assessment, the Government will within 6 
months after the midterm review take effective measures satisfactory to ADB for establishing a 
system of reliable power supply for ICT use in all schools.  
 
84.  Extended School Opening Time. MOPE will ensure through the issuance of a MOPE 
regulation that current school regulations are appropriately adjusted by December 2006 to allow 
extended school opening and operating time for computer rooms for ICT use.  
 
85.  Devolved Financing Experiments for CLSs. The Government will undertake to pilot 
different  methods  of  devolved  funding  to  some  CLSs  to  test  decentralized  resource 
management and will inform ADB on this piloting. 
 
86.  Effective Monitoring and Evaluation. The Government will ensure that a monitoring 
and  evaluation  system  will  be  established  after  loan  effectiveness,  and  be  made  fully 
operational  within  3  months  of  loan  effectiveness,  with  baseline  data  established  within  6 
months of loan effectiveness. 
 
87.  Ethnic Minorities. The Government will ensure the development of learning materials in 
other LOI under the Project and will provide students in other LOI with equal access to ICT 
facilities.  
 
B.   Condition for Loan Effectiveness 
 
88.  The establishment of the PIU headed by a manager with experience and qualification 
acceptable to ADB is a condition for loan effectiveness. 
 
VI.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
89.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of 
ADB and recommend that the Board approve the loan in various currencies equivalent to 
Special  Drawing  Rights  20,408,000  to  the  Republic  of  Uzbekistan  for  the  Information  and 
Communications Technology in Basic Education Project, from ADB’s Special Funds resources 
with an interest charge at the rate of 1% per annum during the grace period and 1.5% per 
annum thereafter; a term of 32 years, including the grace period of 8 years; and such other 
terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft Loan 
Agreement presented to the Board.  
 
 Haruhiko Kuroda

Appendix 3  27 
BASIC EDUCATION SUBSECTOR ANALYSIS 
 
1.  The Government’s stated long-term reform goal for education is to transform the system 
into one that is consistent with a market-oriented economy and a democratic society in the 21st 
century. To realize this national aspiration, the basic education subsector faces key challenges 
to improve its quality, relevance, and equitable access for all. Major constraints are analyzed in 
this appendix (a problem tree analysis is attached).  
 
2.  Governance and Management. Education system governance is characterized by top-
down,  overly  centralized  decision  making.  Until  recently  the  Ministry  of  Public  Education 
(MOPE) had no policy mandate but operated as the implementing agency for policies and 
strategies determined by the Cabinet of Ministers. This situation started to change in 2005 with 
progress in decentralization and the ongoing civil service reform, which aims to provide sector 
ministries with greater policy responsibility. However, MOPE remains weak in strategic planning, 
policy making, and sector management capacity. Coordination between and within ministries 
and  government  agencies  especially  at  the  policy  level  is  systematically  lacking.  The 
widespread  practice  of  compartmentalization  of  responsibilities  often  leads  to  policies  and 
decision making based on insufficient information and with only a restricted understanding of the 
full implications of critical decisions.  
 
3.  Within this highly bureaucratic system, norms rule. For example, in all subjects taught, 
programs and standards set by the central Government strictly dictate the contents and time 
allocated for the subjects, leaving inadequate freedom for schools to adjust to student needs 
and local conditions. State norms fix student-teacher ratios countrywide, and schools have 
neither the power nor budgetary incentives to strive for optimal use of existing resources. 
Schools have little discretionary spending authority over their budgets. As a result, the system 
does not encourage nor reward capacity building in planning and management skills.  
 
4.  Within  MOPE  many  of  these  problems  and  their  consequences  seem  to  now  be 
recognized  and  attempts  are  under  way  for  further  decentralization  of  decision  making  to 
schools and for an upgrading in school management capacity. Of particular concern is the lack 
of effective targeting of the Government’s financial support for the poorest. At present 15% of all 
textbooks (and 100% of grade 1 textbooks) are provided free of charge to schools; an annual 
fund allocation is provided to all schools for winter clothes and shoes. Unfortunately, this pro-
poor support is based on a fixed and equal level of support for every school, irrespective of the 
poverty status of the school. Thus the fund allocation does not target the poorest.1 
 
5.  Curriculum,  Assessment,  and  Structure  of  Education.  Although  attempts  at 
curriculum change have been ongoing since 1991 and some progress has been made in 
reforming  state  education  standards,  the  current  curriculum  continues  to  be  overloaded  in 
content, with too many subjects and an emphasis on factual recall and on repetitive exercises 
rather  than  on  the  development  of  key  skills  and  competencies.  Difficulties  in  achieving 
significant curriculum reform since independence stem from (i) a continuing belief among many 
senior educators that the traditional education model should not be significantly changed, and 
(ii) a lack of knowledge and appreciation of modern curriculum. This has led to approaches to 
curriculum reform that are based on minor amendments of the existing curriculum. Because little

Uzbekistan) in one raion in Ferghana oblast provided poverty data indicating 2% of families living below the poverty 
line in one makhalla and 97% of families living below the poverty line in the other. Both makhallas received the 
same per capita poverty allocations.

28  Appendix 3 
is taken out and much is added, the problem of curriculum overload gets worse and the basic 
structure of the curriculum remains unchanged.  
 
6.  The overloaded curriculum reinforces didactic teacher-centered classroom approaches 
and inhibits any significant shift to student-centered learning because of the time constraints 
imposed by excessive content and the need to move fast in order to complete the syllabuses in 
the time available. Thus the current curriculum fails to provide a suitable framework for the more 
relevant learning outcomes required by the Government as part of its wider education strategy. 
A shift to the development of skills and higher order thinking cannot be delivered if no classroom 
time is available to practice these learning objectives.  
 
7.  The current assessment and testing system is based on student grading by individual 
teachers in the lower grades2 and national tests, which are also administered and marked by 
students’  own  subject  teachers,  who  are  often  also  providing  them  with  paid  examination 
coaching. Apart from potential conflict of interest, this system provides for no effective and 
reliable assessment. It is impossible currently to compare student attainment on a national, 
oblast, raion, or school basis, or to compare progress in the national achievement of attainment 
targets year-on-year or internationally. Current language of instruction (LOI) policy guarantees 
the rights of ethnic minorities to education, but the policy is expensive, and concerns exist about 
inequity in the educational opportunities and quality provided to different language groups. 
Equity in the provision of educational materials is a particular problem because of the relatively 
high unit costs of printing textbook titles in low print runs for small language groups. 
 
8.  The transition from an 11- to a 12-year system of education is expensive and for a 
number of years between 1997 and 2004 it diverted urgently needed funding away from basic 
education. The transition to a 12-year system where students will have to transfer from basic 
schools to specialized professional colleges and academic lyceums after grade 9 will mean that 
many students will have to travel farther to school and will incur additional costs as a result. This 
could have an adverse impact on the progression rate from grade 9 to grade 10, particularly in 
rural areas and for poorer families. The problem is aggravated by less reliable transportation 
systems in rural areas, which exacerbate the problems of student travel to more distant schools.  
 
9.  Education  Financing.  As  a  high  priority,  education  expenditure  in  real  terms  has 
increased every year since 2000, and stood at 9.5% of gross domestic product in 2005.3 
However, basic education was relatively underfunded versus other subsector.4 Aware of the 
deterioration in physical plant and facilities in basic education due to years of underfunding, the 
Government launched the National Program for Basic Education Development 2004–2009 for 
the urgent rehabilitation and upgrading of the whole system. Within the sector, basic education 
expenditure has risen from 45.5% to 50.3% over the past 5 years and will continue to rise 
according to Ministry of Finance.  
 
10.  To help meet growing costs of education reform and maintenance of the basic education 
infrastructure, education financing has been decentralized since 2000 to oblast and raion levels. 
                                                 
2  The current rating system is universally unpopular with students, parents, and teachers. Teachers can often spend 
up to 50% of lesson time completing student grading sheets, which increases the pressure to complete an already 
overloaded curriculum.  
3  The average for the member countries of the Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development is 5.1% for 
the same period.  
4  In 2004 preschool enrolment was just 8.0% of total enrolment in basic and senior secondary education but 
received 14.1% of the total education budget4 and per capita expenditure on senior secondary has been more than 
double per capita expenditure on basic education for the past few years.

Appendix 3  29 
In 2005, 65% of the national education budget is raion financed, 22% is oblast financed, and 
only 13% comes from the state budget. Unfortunately, variations in incomes and tax collection 
capacity have led to increasing differentials over funding for schools. This in turn is seen as a 
main reason for perceived variations across oblasts in the quality of education.  
 
11.  The current norm-based budgeting places high priority on teachers’ remuneration and 
utility at the expense of other items. In 2005, these two items represent almost 87% of the total 
education recurrent budget. Further salary increases agreed in June 2005 might well push the 
salary/social cost component of the basic education recurrent budget over 90% in 2006. While 
increasing teachers’ salary is a good policy in itself, this increase without an increase in the 
general recurrent budget allocation will bring further pressure to bear on already inadequate 
school operating budgets. This may well result in increased demands for parental contributions. 
Such contributions are widely in use and have a disproportionately adverse impact on the poor.  
 
12.  The current financing system, which establishes norms for every aspect of the education 
system; removes management flexibility from oblasts, raions, and individual schools; and makes 
developing  genuine  financial  management  skills  at  any  level  of  the  system  difficult.  The 
establishment of minimum school cost profiles and the provision of devolved, school-based, per 
capita financing budgets based on these profiles would provide the opportunity for all schools to 
take  their  own  priority  financing  decisions,  based  on  their  own  (and  their  community) 
perceptions of priority needs within an adequate budgetary framework. This could rapidly lead to 
better use of available funds and a more cost-effective school financing system,5 and relieve the 
burden on the poor. 
 
13.  Resources  and  Inputs.  Basic  education  suffers  from  insufficient  investment  in 
infrastructure, equipment, and facilities. A 2004 nationwide survey revealed that 40% of schools 
are housed in inappropriate and unfit buildings. There are also wide variations in the supportive 
infrastructure, including power supplies to schools and telecommunications facilities. Resources 
tend to be a particular problem in rural areas, where 80% of schools are located and where 
facilities tend to be worse. Remote schools with difficult access suffer from particular resource 
provision problems and require special consideration. 
 
14.  Lack of sufficient and appropriate learning materials continues to be a problem. Despite 
the success of the textbook rental scheme, high costs of textbooks in those subjects not 
covered by the scheme prevent some parents from purchasing them. There is a clear need 
either to reduce the number of required textbooks or to include all prescribed textbooks within 
the scheme to reduce parental expenditure on textbooks. School libraries have not been funded 
for almost 20 years and school library stock is out-of-date and largely redundant. This has an 
adverse impact on the development of independent learning and the shift to student-centered 
learning. Laboratory equipment and necessary consumables are in short supply. In 2004 only 
18% of basic schools had access to modern personal computers and just 50% of schools had 
access to any form of computers, including those of the Soviet era. Very few basic schools have 
internet access and many schools cannot afford the costs of consumables, maintenance, and 
servicing associated with information and communications technology (ICT) use. Almost no e-
resources are available in Uzbek or other local LOI, which limits the impact of the introduction of 
ICT. Learning materials in the local LOI are in particular short supply, which has an impact on 
equity between different LOIs. 
 
                                                 
5  A United States Agency for International Development experiment in per capita school financing is currently under 
way in Akkurgan raion, Tashkent oblast.

30  Appendix 3 
15.  A reformed basic education system requires appropriately qualified teachers. At present, 
the  large  majority  of  teachers  have  little  previous  experience  or  knowledge  of  alternative 
teaching and learning approaches, and little or no experience of ICT and its potential use across 
the  curriculum.  MOPE  considers  about  50%  of  primary  school  teachers  to  be  unqualified 
(without higher education), and many are overspecialized in narrow subject areas. While the 
Government has improved teachers’ pay significantly over the past 2 years, defined career 
opportunities are lacking. The current in-service teacher training system is distant from the 
schools (located in oblast centers) and infrequent (once every 5 years). Such an inflexible 
system is particularly inconvenient to women who account for over 70% of all teachers. The in-
service teacher training system needs to be urgently improved to retool teachers in a relatively 
short period of time.  
 
16.  Demand-Side  Issues.  Preliminary  results  of  focus  group  interviews6  with  parents, 
students, and teachers indicate general parental satisfaction with schools and teachers (who 
are considered to be doing their best in difficult circumstances) but a high level of dissatisfaction 
with many specific aspects of the current education. Parents are primarily concerned with the 
high costs of education, the poor physical facilities in schools, and the risks to student health 
and welfare of unheated schools in winter with outdoor toilet and washing facilities. Students are 
uncertain of the relevance of the curriculum, apprehensive about future job opportunities, dislike 
the work burden of an overloaded curriculum, and unsatisfied with teachers who are unskilled in 
ICT and new technologies. Increasing costs of higher education imply less access; this is 
becoming a growing concern of students in schools. Teachers are concerned by poor working 
conditions; lack of teaching and learning resources; heavy work burden of the student rating 
system; and lack of clear career opportunities, particularly for women. All of these issues have 
an impact on attitudes to education in the community. They do not yet seem to add up to 
widespread  disenchantment  with  the  system,  although  many  complaints  and  much 
dissatisfaction have been voiced over specific problems.  
 
17.  Student attendance problems may be viewed as an indicator of decreasing demand for 
education, although precisely assessing the exact level of absenteeism overall and in specific 
regions is difficult.7 The main causes of absenteeism are believed to be the high costs of 
education to poor parents. These costs include (i) parental contributions; (ii) opportunity costs of 
alternatives to education (income-generating work outside schools); and (iii) costs and time 
involved in student travel to school in some rural areas, and unwelcoming school conditions in 
winter. Absenteeism is widely seen as a particular problem of poor families in rural areas. 
 
18.  The transition from an 11-year to a 12-year secondary education system may also 
inadvertently affect demand for education. Many students and parents would prefer to maintain 
the existing 11-year system and to complete their secondary education in the same school, 
rather than transfer to another school after grade 9. Although progression rates from grade 9 to 
grade 10 are high, schools report that the additional traveling time and costs incurred in shifting 
to specialized senior secondary schools could be a burden for poor students in rural areas. This 
could affect their decision to continue schooling past grade 9, despite the fact that a large 
majority of students would probably prefer to stay on at school. 
 
                                                 
6  Under the project preparatory technical assistance, 180 focus group interviews and discussions were conducted 
with teachers, students, and parents separately in over 60 schools in all regions of the country.  
7  According to estimates by the World Bank’s Public Expenditure Review 2004, attendance is at about 70%, while

suggests a rate in between the two figures.

Appendix 3  31 
19.  Government Strategy and Policy Framework. Education has been a high priority in 
the Government’s reform agenda and development strategy. Its overall strategic objective has 
been to make the education system more responsive and relevant to the requirements of a 
market economy and democratic society in the 21st century. In pursuit of this objective, a major 
program of education reform was launched in 1997 with the passing of a new education law and 
the adoption of the National Program for Personnel Training.8 The program identified basic 
education  as  one  of  the  principal  areas  of  reform  but  concentrated  on  restructuring  and 
strengthening senior secondary and vocational education during the first and second program 
stages.9 Since then numerous presidential decrees and government resolutions have been 
issued to guide program implementation. Budget allocations for education expenditure have 
risen since 2000, which stands at 8.4% of gross domestic product in 2005 and is forecast to 
continue to rise.  
 
20.  The unveiling of the National Program for Basic Education Development 2004–2009 in 
2004 reaffirms the high priority accorded to basic education and redirects substantial resources 
for implementing the program including the establishment of the School Development Fund as 
an extrabudgetary fund to finance the National Program for Basic Education Development. The 
program aims to overhaul the school system focusing on (i) upgrading poor physical conditions 
and providing key inputs including computer facilities, laboratory equipment, and sport facilities; 
(ii) improving all curricula and syllabuses; (iii) improving teaching methodologies and teaching 
training system; and (vi) supporting schools in poor and remote areas.  
 
21.  The impetus for ICT development was launched by a presidential speech in Parliament 
in  May  2001.  The  Presidential  Degree  of  30  May  2002,  On  Further  Development  of 
Computerization and Introduction of Information and Communication Technologies, established 
the strategic framework for national ICT development including creating a national ICT Steering 
Committee  for  its  implementation.10  The  promulgation  of  the  Programme  of  Further 
Development  of  Computerization  and  Introduction  of  Information  and  Communication 
Technologies for the Period 2002–201011 confirmed the policy directions and basic education as 
a priority sector for ICT development. Funding for the initial investment in hardware and systems 
in basic education (estimated at around $120 million over the next 5 years) will come largely 
from the School Development Fund but the Government is in negotiations with development 
partners to fund additional hardware provision to the subsector within the next few years. 
 
22.  Strategy  and  Assistance  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  Other 
Development Agencies. Consistent with ADB country strategy, basic education is a key area 
of focus of ADB assistance, and ADB is the lead provider of financial assistance in basic 
education in Uzbekistan. ADB’s sector strategy in education has focused on (i) supporting 
efforts to improve quality, relevance, and access to education; and (ii) enhancing national 
capacity  to  manage  sector  reforms.12  Accordingly,  policy  dialogue  and  assistance  in  basic 
education have focused on addressing key issues and challenges of the subsector. ADB has 
provided five loans since 1997.  
                                                 
8  The Constitution of Uzbekistan guarantees free basic education to all citizens.  
9  Major areas of reform identified by the National Program for Personnel Training include (i) improve preschools and 
basic education; (ii) rationalize senior secondary and vocational education; (iii) improve educational management 
and financing; and (iv) establish an effective personnel training system. The three stages of implementation begin 
with the first stage from 1997–2001, second from 2002–2005, and third from 2006–2010. 
10  Uzbek Agency of Communication and Information (UzACI) is the executive for the steering committee. 
11  Cabinet of Ministers Decree 200 of 6 June 2002 plus numerous later attachments.

Uzbekistan.

32  Appendix 3 
23.  To date, ADB’s assistance has constituted overall comprehensive support to implement 
reforms  in  the  education  sector.  This  includes  (i)  establishing  an  overall  coherent  policy 
framework for the sector, which is the focus of the Education Sector Development Program; (ii) 
improving governance, education financing and sector reform management, which is woven into 
all ADB projects; (iii) continuing curriculum and assessment improvement, which is a focus of 
the Second Textbook Development Project;13 (iv) strengthening capacity of teachers and the 
teacher  training  system,  which  is  a  priority  of  both  the  Education  Sector  Development 
Program;14 and the Project; (v) meeting critical investment needs in learning materials especially 
textbooks, school libraries, and ICT facilities, which is a key activity in all projects; and (vi) 
supporting the poor and disadvantaged, which is a focus of all projects. Technical assistance 
from ADB has complemented and supplemented this effort, in particular in the area of institution 
and capacity development.  
 
24.  ADB has maintained close coordination with other development partners to strengthen 
development  impact  through  complementary  programs  and  activities.  A  development 
coordination matrix is in Appendix 6. German Development Assistance Fund (GTZ) provides 
support to the development of vocational education and training. Under its technical assistance 
for  the  Commonwealth  of  Independent  States  program,  the  European  Union  provides 
assistance  to  the  restructuring  of  the  education  system,  which  covers  education  planning, 
financing,  and  management  systems,  with  a  particular  focus  on  vocational  and  higher 
education. The Japanese government focuses its assistance on training of teachers, equipment 
provision, and printing textbooks for improving vocational education.  
 
25.  In  basic  education,  the  United  Nations  Children’s  Fund  and  the  United  Nations 
Education,  Science  and  Cultural  Organization  (UNESCO)  are  conducting  a  monitoring  of 
learning achievements with results due out in August 2005. This will be a timely and useful step 
in improving data on learning outcomes in basic education. The United Nations Development 
Programme has assisted Uzbekistan in preparing a national strategy for ICT development. The 
United  States  Agency  for  International  Development  has  two  ongoing  projects:  one  is 
strengthening learning and teaching, management, and participation at school levels; and the 
other focusing on piloting ICT in schools. The World Bank is preparing its first education project 
for supporting learning materials development for school libraries, teacher training, community 
participation, and school management. ADB has consulted with all of them in preparing the 
Project.  Some  bilateral  partners  provide  support  in  vocational  and  higher  education.  The 
People’s Republic of China recently concluded an agreement to provide a loan of $19 million to 
Uzbekistan in support of the ICT in basic education program. Given the continued progress in 
education reform and increased presence of external partners, and consistent with the Paris 
Declaration, ADB has resumed its proactive and lead role in aid coordination. This will be 
supported by more staff and other resources to ensure that effective coordination will benefit 
Uzbekistan in the form of reduced transaction costs and increased efficiency.

34  Appendix 4 
CURRENT TEACHER TRAINING SYSTEMS AND ISSUES 
 
A.  Pre-Service Teacher Training (PRESETT) 
 
1.  Three types of institution are responsible for providing preservice teacher training for 
general secondary schools. Pedagogical colleges, previously responsible for the training of 
primary school teachers, are now exclusively responsible for training preschool teachers and 
teachers of "special” subjects (e.g., music, gymnastics, and art). The 38 pedagogical colleges 
are planned to be reduced to only 25 by the end of 2005. 
 
2.  Primary  and  secondary  preservice  training  is  now  provided  by  five  pedagogical 
institutes, 16 faculties of pedagogy, and the Tashkent Pedagogical University. Of these, the 
pedagogical institutes and the Pedagogical University generally provide teachers for general 
secondary  education  and  the  faculties  of  pedagogy  provide  teachers  for  the  specialized 
secondary schools (the academic lyceums and professional colleges). The Government wishes 
to increase the enrolment capacity of the faculties of pedagogy to ensure sufficient senior 
secondary teachers for the 12-year educational system, when it becomes compulsory in 2010. 
 
B.  Issues 
 
3.  The National Program for Personnel Training requires all teachers to have at least a first 
degree.  Most  secondary  school  teachers  meet  this  requirement  but  many  primary  school 
teachers (66,000 or 54% of the total in 2003) do not. Most of these teachers work in rural areas 
and a high proportion are women who find retraining difficult to achieve given their family 
commitments.  Approximately  15%  of  these  teachers  are  attempting  to  upgrade  their 
qualifications via correspondence courses or distance education 
 
4.  Although teacher supply is considered to be satisfactory, shortages are experienced in 
foreign languages and in mathematics and science in minority language schools. Preservice 
teacher training curricula and syllabi need to be revised to provide for new methodological skills 
(student-centered and activity-based learning) and to support the reform shift away from factual 
accumulation to the development of skills and higher order thinking.  
 
C.  In-Service Teacher Training 
 
5.  The current in-service training (INSETT) system operates at two levels: (i) the provision 
of residential courses at 16 oblast-based regional in-service teacher training institutes (RITTIs). 
One RITTI specializes in preschools; the A Avloni Institute in Tashkent is responsible for training 
school directors, oblast and raion management staff, and oblast and raion methodologists. The 
courses  are  demand  driven  by  requests  from  schools  to  the  raions;  the  requests  are 
consolidated and passed to oblasts, where they are again consolidated and passed to the 
Ministry of Public Education (MOPE). MOPE scrutinizes the annual requirement and, based on 
budget availability, creates an annual INSETT program for each RITTI. The A Avloni Institute in 
Tashkent is generally responsible for course development, and Avloni designed courses are 
sent to each RITTI, which can amend or adapt the core courses for their own purposes as 
required. All INSETT training in the RITTIs is residential; course duration is generally from 2–4 
weeks. Ordinary teachers are allocated 4 weeks of residential in-service training every 5 years 
in a speciality of their choice (or one agreed with the raion methodologists). Methodologists, 
school directors, and oblast/raion management staff are allocated 4 weeks of residential in-
service training every 3 years; (ii) at the school level, every teacher is paid on the basis that 
20% of their working time will be allocated to continuous professional development (CPD)

Appendix 4  35 
activities. In general, every teacher is required to spend 1 day a week on CPD activities. In 
reality,  this  now  often  takes  the  form  of  lesson  preparation,  marking  students’  work,  or 
completing the paperwork required for the current student rating system. Because operational 
budgets in schools and raions/oblasts have deteriorated, the majority of teachers probably no 
longer engage in meaningful CPD activities on a weekly basis.1 The teacher focus group 
interviews in the project preparatory technical assistance school survey suggest that many 
teachers feel the need for far more upgrading than they currently receive, particularly on ICT, 
student-centred and individual learning, higher order thinking skills, etc. 
  
6.  The RITTIs are funded by the MOPE budget. A Avloni will receive an annual budget in 
2004/05 of around $0.5 million. This budget is supposed to cover staff salaries (63 permanent 
staff), course development and printing costs, utilities and maintenance, other operational costs, 
transport for trainees, and subsistence and accommodation for trainees. In 2004/05 A Avloni will 
provide approximately 18,000 person-weeks of training to 4,500 trainees. Thus the approximate 
unit cost of 1 week of residential training at the A Avloni ITTI is approximately $28 per person 
per week. A Avloni also houses the Distance Education Development Centre funded by the 
Education Sector Development Program (ESDP).2 The RITTIs are basically trainers. The A 
Avloni in-service teacher training institute is a course developer and a trainer. None of the 
RITTIs  consider  themselves  to  be  inspectors  and  quality  control  over  the  training  is  not 
exercised by the RITTIs but by MOPE.  
 
7.  MOPE estimates that 75–80% of the RITTIs have modern computer rooms. A Avloni, for 
example,  has  five  classrooms  each  with  10  Pentium  I  machines.  The  ESDP  will  upgrade 
equipment in the RITTI computer facilities. 
 
D.  Issues 
 
8.  The current system of INSETT is widely considered to be unsatisfactory for the current 
demands  from  the  education  system3  for  the  following  reasons:  it  is  (i)  inflexible;  (ii)  too 
centralized; (iii) poorly targeted; (iv) infrequent; and (v) residential, which is a problem for many 
women teachers who also have families to look after, particularly in poor rural areas, and who 
would prefer to have training closer to home and more flexibly delivered. The INSETT system 
needs to be adjusted to become more flexible; closer to schools; more responsive to a rapidly 
changing  education  environment  and  the  new  demands  placed  upon  teachers  by  MOPE 
policies, in line with the personal and professional skills required by teachers, students, schools, 
and parents; and much more highly prioritized and targeted on the key skills needed to support 
reform. Ideally, a revitalized and redirected INSETT system should also provide incentives for 
teachers by providing salary premiums for the achievement of high priority courses/skills 
 
9.  School-based CPD, while conceptually excellent, is failing because of a lack of allocated 
budgets to provide a comprehensive, high-quality program; and lack of school-based training 
and development activities and facilities, which are in line with current teacher needs. Most 
                                                 
1  A few teachers have reported that INSETT costs at raion/oblast level have been deducted from their salaries. 
2  ADB. 2002. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors on Proposed Loans to the 
Republic of Uzbekistan for the Education Sector Development Program. Manila.    
3  The need to adjust and rethink INSETT via the RITTI system is implicit in the objectives of the ESDP. The rector of 
the A Avloni ITTI also believes that current INSETT is too centralized, too irregular, and too inflexible and that 
reforms are overdue. He argues however that the basic RITTI system should be retained but should be made more 
responsive to the needs of schools and teachers. The concept of the school clusters restores the continuous 
professional development capacity of the system at the school level and should not affect the reforms in INSETT 
currently under way via the ESDP.

36  Appendix 4 
raion methodologists themselves require intensive training in many of the new skills, and most 
teachers are not in a position to develop appropriate skills in other teachers. MOPE also 
considers that suitably qualified, appropriately skilled staff are lacking in many of the RITTIs and 
that intensive programs of inspection, training, and recruitment are necessary. 
 
10.  Meetings  with  the  Teacher  Education  Department  in  MOPE  confirm  that  MOPE  is 
concerned by current variations in training quality between different RITTIs. A new MOPE 
resolution is in preparation, which will send teams of inspectors to each RITTI to report on 
quality and performance and to recommend improvements. A recent inspection of the Khorezm 
in-service teacher training institute comprised two representatives from MOPE, two from other 
RITTIs, and one oblast deputy director of education. A RITTI rectors council meets every 2 
months, chaired by the first deputy minister of education. It provides a forum for raising issues of 
concern.  
 
11.  MOPE considers that variations in INSETT quality within the RITTI system have the 
following  causes:  (i)  lack  of  suitably  trained  staff  (only  10%  of  RITTI  staff  have  higher 
qualifications; 34% are basically qualified while 56% are considered to be underqualified); (ii) 
RITTI staff are themselves in urgent need of training and upgrading; (iii) a number of the oblast 
RITTIs have substandard facilities; and (iv) inadequate operational budgets tend to operate 
against the consistent delivery of high quality in-service teacher training.

PROJECT MANAGEMENT CHART 
   
 
 
 
Project Steering Committee (to be integrated with the PSCs of other projects)
 
 
 The Ministry of Public Education (MOPE) will be the Executing Agency. The Cabinet  Education Reform 
 of Ministers (COM) will appoint the project steering committee (PSC). Membership  Implementation & 
 will be drawn from the COM, Ministry of Public Education (MOPE), Ministry of  Monitoring Unit 
 Higher and Senior Secondary Education (MOHSSE), Ministry of Finance (MOF) ,  This is the education 
       
and Ministry of Economy (MOE), Uzbek Agency for Communication and  reform monitoring 
 
Information, Uzbektelecom, and Uzbekenergo. The chair will be a senior official  unit reporting to the 
 
appointed by the COM. The PSC is responsible for overall project coordination. The  COM 
 
PSC will meet quarterly to review project status, discuss implementation issues, 
 
ensure coordination among different ministries, resolve issues, provide broad 
 
guidance, and review and advise on the annual implementation plan.  
 
 
 
 
  Project Director (a joint appointment with the project directors of other 
  projects) 
 
 
The project director will be a MOPE top official responsible for supervising the 
 
MOPE units that will be most involved in project implementation. The project director 
 
will provide general guidance to the PIU on policy issues in accordance with 
 
decisions made by the SPC; arrange PSC meetings, present quarterly reports to the 
 
PSC, and ensure coordination of project implementation within MOPE; be 
 
responsible for MOPE policy inputs.  
 
 
 
 
 
                     Project Manager
 
 
The project manager will be appointed under the project director and will be 
 
responsible for coordinating and supervising the work of the PIU.  
 
    
 
 
 
 
  Project Implementation Unit
   
  The PIU, which consists of the project manager and staff is responsible for day-to-
  day management of the Project (including finance and overall management). The 
  PIU prepares the detailed implementation plan for the Project; annual reports, and 
progress reports to the PSC and project director. The PIU will be responsible for 
 
project implementation, procurement and recruitment, staff development, finance 
 
and accounting, and monitoring and evaluation. It will require 6–8 full-time staff 
  who will be recruited based on past project implementation experience. The 
  Project PIU will be established in accordance with the Government’s decision 
related to the establishment and financing of the PIU, which will be covered by 
 
retroactive financing. To ensure timely implementation of the Project, MOPE will 
 
appoint a project manager before measures for rationalizing project management 
  are put in place. The PIU will be established in the same premises as the PIUs of 
  the other two ongoing projects, and will coordinate closely with them across PIU 
  functions, including sharing of staff where feasible.

Appendix 13  55 
MONITORING PROJECT PERFORMANCE  
 
1.  Monitoring  and  evaluation  (M&E)  systems  are  programmed  to  be  designed  and 
operational  within  the  first  month  of  project  effectiveness.  The  baseline  studies  will  be 
completed within 12 months of loan effectiveness. The United Nations Educational, Scientific, 
and Cultural Organization and United Nations Children’s Fund MLA exercise, due for completion 
in the fourth quarter 2005, will be an important source for establishing baseline data on learning 
achievements. M&E will be conducted annually; and an annual report on progress and problems 
will be compiled and published as soon as possible after data collection, inputting, and analysis. 
 
2.  The M&E will focus on process and outcome indicators. For process, the M&E will focus 
on (i) development of national information and communications technology (ICT) strategies and 
policies, (ii) establishment and operationalization of cluster leader schools (CLSs), (iii) coverage 
of initial teacher training programs for CLSs and for non-CLS cluster schools, and (iv) availability 
and usability of e-learning materials. 
 
3.  For impact, the M&E will focus on (i) quantitative assessments of improvements in 
learning outcomes and teachers practice; (ii) qualitative assessments based on teacher-student 
reactions, and frequency and effectiveness of classroom usage of learning materials developed; 
(iii) outcomes of the pilot projects; (iv) effectiveness of continuous professional development and 
school clustering; and (v) fulfillment of pro-poor and gender equity objectives.  
 
4.  The main data collection activities will be (i) direct observation of the activities of CLSs 
and cluster leader schools; (ii) surveys and assessments administered through school clusters 
to CLSs, cluster schools, teachers, students, parents, and the wider school community; (iii) 
focus group discussions with selected parents, teachers, students, makhallas (communities), 
and oblast/raion staff; (iv) data collection direct from the project implementation unit on activities 
and completion rates; and (v) interviews with key Ministry of Public Education and Ministry of 
Finance staff members and policy makers. 
 
5.    The  regular,  annual  M&E  evaluations  operating  with  consistent  year-on-year 
performance indicators represent a longitudinal study on all of the key development aspects of 
the Project, including the progress of teachers’ professional development and improvement of 
learning outcomes. Proposed indicators will include the following:  
 
(i)   Process. This includes the following: 
  
(a)  National ICT strategy approved, published, and operational by project 
effectiveness  and  achievable.  Second  phase  ICT  strategy  developed, 
approved, and available by 2009 
(b)     Sustainable financial profile and projections for ICT in basic education are 
developed by the Ministry of Finance and available by 2009. 
(c)  Adequate recurrent budgets sufficient to ensure ongoing ICT operations 
in  all  schools  are  regularly  made  available  year-on-year  during  the 
Project. 
(d)  All schools designated as “poor” are provided with ICT hardware and 
software and have no operational constraints by the end of the Project. 
(e)  Seventy percent of CLSs are selected from schools designated as poor 
and/or rural schools. 
(f)  At least 80% of school clusters are operating effectively by 2010.

SUMMARY POVERTY REDUCTION AND SOCIAL STRATEGY  
 
A.  Linkages to the Country Poverty Analysis 
       
Is the sector identified as a national    Yes  Is the sector identified as a national   Yes 
priority in country poverty analysis?      priority in country poverty partnership   
      No  agreement?      No 
Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Uzbekistan:  
 
The Project aims to improve quality, relevance, and equitable access to basic education for all students, including 
students in poor and remote areas. The Project will contribute to the following social development outcomes: (i) enable 
students and educators to participate more effectively in the knowledge-based economy by virtue of enhanced 
problem-solving skills, improved capacity to study independently, ability to work with information, and ability to apply 
key skills in real job settings; (ii) support the creation of new electronic materials that help the teachers to shift to a 
student-centered learning environment in which teachers play a learning facilitator role; (iii) ensure that all students 
have access to quality educational materials through e-learning and support conditions for equal access to      (ICT) 
with enhanced education services based on ICT; (iv) develop teacher and education management capacity to 
incorporate new educational technology into teaching practice, produce learning materials, and use ICT-based 
management system; and (v) improve the existing     (INSETT) system to be closer to users, more flexible, and more 
frequent, thus more effective. 
 
The Project will have a direct beneficial impact on about 130,000 poor students in grades 5–9 enrolled in the 700 
during 2006–2011.1 Specific pro-poor measures of the Project include (i) having about 70% of the 860 CLSs from poor 
schools; (ii) improved power supply to all schools, which will ensure proper working of the ICT facilities installed, as 
well as meet general lighting and heating needs during the winter;2 (iii) pilot testing connectivity especially for rural and 
remote areas; (iv) facilitating access to rural teachers, students, and local communities; and (v) opening ICT facilities 
in schools to local communities, which will benefit an estimated 1 million households. The Project will provide ICT 
facilities and internet connections to all schools, rich and poor, urban and rural. This is pro-poor since it will help bridge 
the internal digital divide. The Project will address the issue of increasing parental contributions, which burdens the 
poor disproportionately, by ensuring that the full costs of ICT in schools are borne by the public sector with no parental 
contributions required for ICT use in schools.  
 
In 2000 Uzbekistan signed the Dakar Framework for Action and in 2003 published the National Action Plan for 
Education for All. The action plan supports the basic principle of inclusion and integration of children with special 
needs into the general education system. The Department for Special Education of the Ministry of Public Education 
submitted a draft resolution to the Government at the end of March 2005 aiming to provide a formal policy framework 
and strategy for enhancing education quality and conditions for children with special needs. The Project will pilot 
inclusive education through (i) public education and awareness campaign, and policy dialogue; (ii)         (CLSs) to 
include training and e-materials for children with special needs; and (iii) linking the pilot project with other related Asian 
Development Bank projects such as RITTI course development activities under the ESDP and provision of teaching 
materials i.e., Braille textbooks to schools under the STDP. 
 
The incorporation of ICT into the schools can greatly benefit community involvement in school activities. The school 
will provide the possibility for parents to gain access to technology and training. Hence, the schools with ICT can 
become part of larger initiatives to offer technology access to communities, particularly in rural areas. Up to 1 million 
households are expected to be able to access ICT via community access schemes such as a telecenters or school-
based internet cafes.  
 
B.  Poverty Analysis         Targeting Classification: General intervention  
 
 
What type of poverty analysis is needed?  
 
The World Bank Living Standard Assessment (2003) shows that an estimated 27.5% of the population or 6.8 million 
people live at or below the poverty line. Of these, approximately one third or 2.3 million people are classified as 
extremely poor.  Poverty is significantly higher in rural than in urban areas  (30.5% versus 22.5%) and 69% of the poor  
 
                                                 
1  This assumes that 27% of the students on average are from poor families, a poverty indicator based on the Living 
Standard Assessment of the World Bank 2003.  
2  Lack of heating in winter is cited as one reason that some parents do not let their children go to school in winter.

58  Appendix 14 
 
and 72% of the extreme poor are found in rural Uzbekistan. Poverty is also associated with specific regions. Thus 
poverty is relatively low in the Tashkent region (9.2%) and relatively very high in Kashkadarya (62.6%) and in 
Karakalpakstan (36.4%). This is partly the result of environmental factors but also of a bias in public policy that has 
allocated far more public investment, credit, subsidies, and other scarce resources to the urban areas while broadly 
neglecting rural areas.3 
 
The survey of 30 makhallas (communities) during the project preparatory technical assistance shows that the 
incidence of poverty also has remarkable regional contrast within oblasts. The incidence of economically vulnerable 
families varied from 97% in one makhallas in Yosobon raion, Fergana oblast to 2% in Shaykhantokhur raion in 
Tashkent City. Within Fergana oblast two raions recorded the incidence of economically vulnerable families at 7%, 
while the third estimated at 97%. However, a high proportion of the poor in Uzbekistan tend to be rich in human 
capital. Thus most have at least 9 years of education. The survey indicates that poor households are distinguished by 
the following features: (i) high unemployment or underemployment, (ii) minimum educational qualifications, (iii) more 
than three children per family, (iv) reduced access to land of good quality, and (v) less integrated into the market 
economy. 
 
Poverty and social assessments were carried out to inform project design. They revealed the following: (i) inequality 
and inequity in access (digital divide) in the regions from geographic perspective: between rural and urban schools 
and between rich and poor schools and households; (ii) access to ICT is very limited both in urban and rural schools, 
which hinders future generations of Uzbek students from have the necessary skills to participate fully in the knowledge 
economy; (iii) demand for parental contribution for ICT could be a severe financial problem for the poor; (iv) 
decentralization of the education budget—only 5 of 14 oblasts are self sufficient in taxation and the central budget is 
used as a safety net to provide support for oblasts that cannot balance their budgets; (v) lack of infrastructure such as 
reliable power supplies, nonsecure wiring from computer installation, and 82% of schools have never seen or used a 
modern IBM compatible computer; and (vi) lack of teachers’ knowledge on use of ICT. 
 
C.  Participation Process 
 
Is there a stakeholder analysis?    Yes     No  
 
The main stakeholder groups are students, teachers, education managers (both administrators within the education 
system and policymakers), teacher educators, developers of learning materials, private sector groups dealing in ICT, 
teacher educators both preservice and in-service, parent-teacher associations, and communities. During the project 
design  and  preparation  phase,  stakeholders  participated  as  members  of  working  groups  to  design  various 
components, and participated in workshops and in preparing implementation plans. Three national workshops, 180 
focus group discussions in all 14 regions of the country, which involved over 40 makhallas and 60 schools, were held 
during the preparation phase. The project design also involved consultations with nongovernment organizations and 
other civil society organizations.  
 
Is there a participation strategy?     Yes                   No 
National  public  campaign  to  ensure  that  all  stakeholders  especially  teachers,  parents,  students,  educators, 
policymakers, private sector, and civil society organizations are fully informed will be conducted during project 
implementation. The campaign will be launched to complement the National Conference on ICT in Basic Education 
scheduled for November 2005, with regular updates on progress of implementation throughout the first 2 years of 
project implementation.  
 
 
D.  Gender Development 
 Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
 
Uzbekistan has made efforts to ensure that its inherited good education indicators and are maintained. Universal 
access to basic primary and secondary school education (grades 1–9) has been maintained, and the literacy rate is 
almost 100% for men and women. According to the Household Baseline Survey (2001/02) data, approximately 92% of 
men and 93% of women in the 25–34 year-old age group had some upper secondary or higher levels of schooling. 
The interim Report on Welfare Improvement Strategy of the Republic of Uzbekistan (2005) showed that the enrolment 
rates between boys and girls (90.9% of boys and 90.5% of girls) are equal. However, the quality of education at all 
levels of education is not being maintained. 
 
                                                 
3  Corniaga. 2003. An Overall Strategy for Pro-Poor Growth in Growth and Poverty Reduction in the Next Decade in Uzbekistan. 
United Nations Development Programme for the Government of Uzbekistan, Tashkent.

Appendix 14  59 
The Project will provide for an assessment to examine the issue of gender stereotyping through analysis of e-materials 
content and identify strategy for improving the presentation of gender roles and issues. The Project will ensure that 
girls and boys have equal access to all required learning e-materials and ICT. The improved INSETT system, which is 
closer to schools and more flexible, will benefit at least 12,600 women teachers who account for 70% of the teaching 
force in CLSs, with far more women of teachers in the school system to be benefited during the life of the Project. In 
addition other issues with gender implications to be monitored include analysis of education materials for gender 
biases and stereotyping women.
